TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst he is here, my question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask: if Australia is, as the World Bank would have us believe, potentially the world's richest nation, why, under the leadership of Mr Keating, the new paramount chief, do we have a 28 per cent youth unemployment record; 753,000 Australians looking for a job; the equivalent of $10,000 foreign debt for each man, woman and child in this country; a current account deficit of banana republic proportions; mortgages on many houses which now exceed the value of those houses; and the highest real interest rates in the developed world? Doesn't it further demonstrate how, under Mr Keating, with his hands on the levers for nearly 13 years, Labor has so failed ordinary Australians, who have in fact grown poorer under Mr Keating's administration?

—It must have come as a terrible shock to the opposition to read the press reports this morning about the wealth base of this country because it does put into remarkably stark context some of the doomsaying that we have been hearing for transparent political reasons for so long.The truth of the matter is that on the World Bank calculations you are talking about per capita wealth by Australians of something over $1.1 million. That is the wealth entitlement for every man, woman and child—to coin a phrase—in this country. If you do not like the reality of that kind of analysis, if you think that is artificial, how artificial is it to compare the debt figure of $10,000—as compared to $1.1 million—which you claim is the debt burden for every individual Australian?

PARA.TAB: Of course, the truth of the matter is that there is no such thing as a debt burden upon individual Australians. There is a debt burden upon a great many private enterprises in this country because they have borrowed the capital from overseas—and very large swags of capital overseas—in order to put to work the productive investments that have made this country the wealthy country that it is and the country that it is in terms of the standard of living of ordinary Australians, which puts us in very good shape indeed by any international comparison.

The debt that this country owes, which Senator Hill keeps referring to, is overwhelmingly private sector debt used for productive purposes. It is not owed in any sense by governments and it is not owed in any sense by taxpayers. The wealth is a reality, as the World Bank has acknowledged, and we are right up there on top of the tree. In comparison to that wealth, and given our capacity to service the kind of debt that we have as easily as we can with the level of exports that we are presently generating, from that point of view—from the balance sheet point of view—the position of ordinary Australians is very good indeed and, historically, as good I think as it has ever been.

Of course, it is not only the balance sheet part of the equation that matters. What matters when you are determining the health of the economy is all the rest of the dynamic current income considerations. Here we are talking about an economy that is growing at a sustainable rate of just under four per cent, which puts us right at the top of the OECD tree. We are talking about an economy that is doing that at the same time as maintaining a sustainable inflation rate of around three per cent, which puts us in an admirable long-term position to maximise the returns for ordinary Australians of this economic growth that we have been experiencing now for an unprecedented 16 quarters.

We are talking about interest rates, which are not a disincentive to industrial investment in the way they have been in the past because they are now running at among the lowest levels for decades. That is also the case for the housing side of the equation. No-one wants to see those rates increasing, but there is no sign whatsoever that they will, given the basic underlying health of the economy.

The story of employment and unemployment is again a stunningly successful one in terms of the extent to which we have met the promises that we have made—not only met them, but overwhelmingly exceeded those promises. Five hundred thousand new jobs, we said, in the course of this particular government. Well 2 1/2 years into the government, 675,000 new jobs; a very significant diminution in the unemployment rate; and a very significant improvement in the situation so far as long-term unemployed are concerned—youth unemployed in particular. This is a problem which we have all acknowledged. It was the central problem in the Australian economy and it is a problem that we have been dealing with in ways that the figures amply reveal.

So every which way you look at it—when you look at the quality of the investment, the profitability of the private sector which is necessary to sustain that investment and every other indicator—there is no substance whatsoever to Senator Hill's question. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister demonstrates just how out of touch he is when he describes as `stunningly successful' three-quarters of a million Australians out of work and a quarter of all young Australians unable to find a job.
—Is there a question there?

—The supplementary question is: why are so many ordinary Australians doing so badly under your administration if this nation has so much potential? Mustn't the blame fairly and squarely lie at the fault of your administration—13 years of letting ordinary Australians down?

—Every developed economy in the world has had a significant problem in recent years with unemployment. Every developed economy in the world has had a significant problem with youth unemployment. We have been no exception because the fundamental character of the economy and the way in which the productive enterprises and public enterprises in this economy have worked has created a very difficult situation.

PARA.TAB: What we have done is to redress that situation more than, I think, any other country in the world. Our social policy and our economic policy—the Accord and the Working Nation strategies—which have put in place the capacity to bring youngsters, particularly long-term unemployed youngsters, and others into the economy, have been seen everywhere around the world as a triumph of intelligent policy making. They have made a very significant difference already to those out of work, and the figures are there to prove it—with nearly 200,000 of the long-term unemployed back to work and 675,000 jobs created. The long-term trend is for a very significant decline, and there is certainly a capacity to meet the target we have set ourselves of five per cent by the end of the century. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Bob Collins, and it relates to the continuing drought, particularly in New South Wales and Queensland. Minister, can you advise if you have received any evidence at this stage that the nucleus of the Australian core breeding herds are under serious threat? Has the government given serious consideration to the need for the reintroduction of fodder subsidies?
—Mr President—

PARA.TAB: Senator Panizza interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, I know what you think about fodder subsidies, Senator Panizza, and it is not what the shadow minister thinks. You have been kind enough to go on the public record in this chamber with it.

PARA.TAB: Before I answer the particularities of the question, I do want to draw the Senate's attention to the extremely useful rain experienced in much of New South Wales over the weekend. For those who have received it, it has been very effective. The quite gentle but persistent rain has certainly guaranteed that a lot of people who would not have got crops harvested will now do so. One can only hope that it does signal a return to a regular spring weather pattern, particularly for those wheat growers who desperately need this sort of rain over the next few weeks.

On the question of the core breeding herd and the destocking of that herd and the need to introduce fodder subsidies in order to maintain it, I was quite dismayed to read the statements made by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, on a drought trip recently in New South Wales. He said that the coalition would reintroduce fodder subsidies because of the massive problem of the reduction in the national breeding herd.

The facts are that there is simply no evidence that this is so. During the present drought, ABARE expected the Australian cattle herd to fall from 25.3 million head in 1991-92 to 24 million head in 1994-95. Preliminary results from the agricultural census for the 1994-95 season show that, contrary to expectations and contrary to the advice that Mr Howard is obviously receiving, the Australian cattle herd has increased over the drought years from 25.2 million head in March 1993 to 26.2 million head at March this year. The final census results are expected next month. These figures are particularly relevant when you consider that, when the fodder subsidy proposal was raised about a year ago by John Anderson, we costed the proposal at that time at somewhere in the vicinity of $50 million a month to finance—that is simply the fodder subsidy on its own.

The final census on those herd numbers is expected next month, but I was dismayed to hear Mr Howard say that the coalition would introduce what was a sadly rorted and misguided scheme when it was brought in by the last conservative government on the basis of a reduction in the national breeding herd. That is not only wrong—the herd has increased in size, not decreased, over the drought. I believe the federal opposition leader displayed a dangerous ignorance of the real situation when he made this statement. I might add that people who do know something about primary industry, like Senator Panizza, have publicly advocated their opposition to things like fodder subsidies on previous occasions.

The last time this matter was examined—that is, what the results of fodder subsidies were when they were introduced; that massive cost to the Australian taxpayers—the results of that examination concluded that not only were they rorted to the back teeth, because they were not discriminatory, but they also increased the severity of future droughts by lowering the incentive for farmers to adopt their own support strategies to the great detriment of the environment. That, apart from the financial side of it, is something, I would think, that has to be carefully considered by the coalition.

A scheme that discourages self-reliance, exacerbates land degradation and has been subject to widespread rorts in the past is not something which this government would consider reintroducing. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. There have also been statements in the media about the need for the re-inclusion of drought policy under the natural disaster relief arrangements. Does the government have any plans in this regard?

—No. The federal opposition leader told farmers in Dubbo that the coalition's policy would embrace the drought relief blueprint released last year by John Anderson but would also retain current government federal policies. In fact, to quote Mr Howard—and I have done it before—he said, `Our policy will pick up the approach of the government.' We are not considering returning drought to the national disaster relief arrangements where assistance was granted to all producers, regardless of their need or of their current and long-term financial status.

PARA.TAB: The fact that drought administration has been taken out of the natural disaster relief arrangements, I point out again, has only recently been reconfirmed by all primary industry ministers in Australia. Only a short time ago at the ARMCANZ meeting in Perth all primary industry ministers, both Labor and conservative—regardless of their political affiliations—reconfirmed their support for the national drought policy, which the coalition now says it will tear to pieces.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Assuming the P&O deal falls over, can you confirm that the Department of Finance has calculated that the Australian National Line has a net negative economic value and that the Commonwealth will need to pay for the ANL to be taken off its hands? Do you agree that Minister Brereton's claim last year that you couldn't give the ANL away is now actually correct as Australians will have to pay to sell their shipping line?

—The matter of the employees of ANL, whom the coalition seems to have scant regard for, is being carefully handled by the government at the moment and the future of ANL will continue to be advanced. Regrettably, ANL has undergone quite severe losses, largely as a result, as the Senate has already been advised, of the depredations of very large fleets of freighters now being operated around the world both from the former Soviet Union and from China. These fleets are cutting rates to the bone as a result of the need to obtain foreign currency. As a result of those depredations on ANL, the company did undergo an escalation of those losses in just the past few years. Therefore, it is essential that the future of ANL is handled carefully for the benefit of the employees of the organisation as well as for the company itself. That is a matter that is being taken in hand by the government at the moment.

—Mr President, on a point of order: I noted from Senator Collins's actions that he did not appear to hear the first part of the question. Therefore, it may not be his fault that he has not yet answered it. The question was: can you confirm that the Department of Finance has calculated that ANL has a net negative economic value? That is the part of the question that Senator Collins is being asked to address.
—There is no point of order. I am not in a position to dictate how the minister answers the question.

—Mr President, you have just said once again that you are not in a position to dictate. No-one is asking you to dictate. I am simply saying to you that the question was very specific on a matter to which the minister did not refer at all. It may be because he did not hear it, but the least you can do is concede the fact that he did not answer the question. No-one is asking you to dictate to him.
—Order! There is nothing new in what you have said and I have already ruled on it.

—I ask the minister again: has the Department of Finance calculated that the ANL has net negative value? Also, will the minister inform the Senate and the Australian people, when ANL is sold, will we as taxpayers have any ongoing commitments by way of loan, direct or indirect—or any other way—as a result of the sale.

—I ignored the first part of the question because it is not a matter for my portfolio responsibilities, nor the portfolios I represent in this chamber. It should have been directed to the minister representing the Minister for Finance. In respect of the last part of the senator's question, the facts are that all parties engaged in this exercise for the good of ANL have agreed to defer the sale until 31 October. Arrangements for the benefit of the company and its employees will be finalised in the meantime.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. Minister, last week in Adelaide you hosted the second meeting of the APEC ministers responsible for small and medium sized business. I understand that other events were held in conjunction with the ministerial meeting, including an exhibition of small and medium enterprises and a business conference. I also understand that efforts were made to match SMEs with potential partners and customers. Can you explain the relationship between the ministerial and business events? In particular, can you summarise the main outcomes from the ministerial meeting?

—I thank Senator Murphy for his question. I am very pleased to be able to report that for four and a half days last week in Adelaide there were a number of major events dealing with small business in Australia and in the APEC region. Since the formation of APEC we had the first full ministerial meeting of APEC ministers held in Australia. I am pleased that it was for ministers responsible for small and medium enterprises. Eighteen ministers attended.

PARA.TAB: We had, in conjunction with that, an APEC opportunity at which nearly 800 SMEs from around the APEC region, including nearly 200 from the 17 economies other than our own, were represented. Just over 500 Australian SMEs attended. Through the assistance of the export access program and participation in APB-NET, those SMEs were matched up and were encouraged to network and create business alliances so that they could show that they could do international business, international trade even though they are small and medium sized businesses. The APEC opportunity was an outstanding success and I want to pay tribute in particular to the support of the ACCI and their subsidiary, APB-NET, plus all the other business organisations in APEC that arranged to send representatives.

The ministerial meeting had two very distinct features that are of note. First of all, without reservation the ministers unanimously carried a resolution and issued a communique committing themselves to support the Bogor declaration of free trade for mature economies by 2010 and for developing economies by 2020. What was fascinating was the input of the business communities from all the APEC economies. They themselves recognised that SMEs have a greater advantage for developing free trade in our region than any other sector and were very positive in encouraging all ministers present to take the same attitude. Through the two days of discussion at the ministerial meeting those views were very strongly put.

Another unique feature of the ministerial meeting that I am not aware happens at other international ministerial meetings was that SME representatives from each of the economies were invited to join the ministerial discussion for a session of over two hours at which SME representatives spoke directly to ministers about the policy developments they wanted throughout APEC and the issues they wanted APEC to deal with. The specific business forum and APB-NET made detailed submissions which were circulated publicly about the changes they wanted made and the policy developments and arrangements that would encourage free trade and economic growth in the APEC region. Ministers responded to those suggestions and many of them were incorporated in the final communique.

This was the biggest international ministerial meeting in Adelaide's history. It was one of the biggest held in Australia and the first APEC ministerial meeting. The 700 SMEs that attended, from what I have been told, formed the biggest gathering of international SMEs in Australia's history. Combining the two was a significant event, not just for Adelaide and Australia, but for APEC itself, in which we had a commitment to the free trade objectives of Bogor. I believe that will become a major development for SMEs. I conclude by saying that the next ministerial meeting will be held in September next year in the Philippines. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, President Chirac had a fair point, didn't he, when he said, `If the Australian government is so outraged by the nuclear issue, I would have thought they wouldn't be selling uranium.' Doesn't this highlight the hypocrisy, or at least ambivalence, in Australia's policy, particularly following the reported comments of President Chirac that Australian uranium is going into French bombs? Could this be a case of our reaping what we have sown since the resumption of uranium exports to France in 1987?

—I have to say that, from some points of view, President Chirac's statement about Australian uranium is one of the more disingenuous of those that have been uttered in recent times. He not only knows perfectly well that if Australia takes unilateral action to sever our uranium contacts we will be in the position of having to make very substantial compensation payments to our own uranium producers, in the order of some $80 million, for the duration of the contracts; he also knows perfectly well, or his advisers and his industry certainly know very well, that France stands to make a windfall gain of $30 million to $40 million as a result of being able to buy, currently, uranium on the world market at lower prices than it is presently contracted to pay. So there is a spectacular element of economic self-interest in this which one should appreciate at the outset.

PARA.TAB: The second point to make about President Chirac's statement and, indeed, those of other French ministers—defence minister Millon among them—is that, either because they have been uninformed or because of some other reason, they have fundamentally mis-stated the reality of the conditions of supply of Australian uranium to France. The reality is that Australian uranium be supplied pursuant to the safeguard system. It means that there is an absolute guarantee to the extent that one can guarantee it, pursuant to the safeguard system as it presently operates, and which does govern the whole control of uranium supplies worldwide, that there is no Australian uranium, in the sense that the safeguard system operates, going into nuclear weapons production.

If it is the case that the French are saying that their uranium supplies from Australia are not properly subjected to the safeguard arrangements that we have entered into treaty arrangements to guarantee, they are immediately drawing a question mark about all of their sources of uranium supply from elsewhere around the world and fundamentally putting at risk the operation of that safeguard system, and thereby putting at risk the whole nuclear non-proliferation treaty process. The nuclear non-proliferation treaty is a very carefully balanced exercise. It involves a trade-off between the interests of those who possess nuclear technology and the materials to supply the use of that technology and those who do not.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call that a sell-out.

—It is not a sell-out, Senator Margetts, because, if there had not been a trade-off of that kind, we would not have had a nuclear non-proliferation treaty signed in the 1960s and we would by now have nearly 30 countries around the world possessing nuclear weapons. I know you do not like the idea of nuclear power production around the place, but that particular willingness to make available nuclear technology for power production for peaceful purposes, and that particular willingness on the part of those countries which had the technology or the raw materials to make available that technology and raw materials to those countries which did not, was the price we have paid for ensuring that we do not have something like 30 countries now possessing nuclear weapons.

PARA.TAB: Nobody doubts that that is the reason why the nuclear non-proliferation treaty has been far more successful than the sceptics back in the 1960s thought it would be—because there is that element of reciprocal obligation. Because the non-nuclear countries—those who did not possess the technical capacity and who wanted to be able to acquire that technology—knew they could do so, they were prepared to enter into the bargaining question and prepared to acknowledge the continuing reality, as much as they hated it and still hate it, of nuclear weapons possession by the existing big five. That is the nature of the deal, and the international safeguard system to ensure that uranium and other technology cannot be applied for other than peaceful purposes is the essence of that continued system. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1989 flag swapping incident highlighted that safeguards can be bypassed, but is it not true that Australia's ambivalence towards the nuclear industry as a whole actually exposes us as a soft touch, makes it easier for the French to come into the South Pacific area and undermines our capacity to be taken as seriously as Australians would wish us to be?
—Come into the South Pacific?

—To use the South Pacific. What do you say to the 75 per cent of Australians who, according to the AGB McNair poll, say that the federal government—and a future opposition government as well—should stop the export of uranium to France?

—We are not ambivalent on nuclear matters. We oppose absolutely and unequivocally the possession by anybody of nuclear weapons. We want to eliminate nuclear weapons in those countries that have them and we are doing everything we can to achieve that result.

PARA.TAB: We do acknowledge the reality that the price to be paid for having a successful and operative non-proliferation system is a willingness by us, as a uranium producer and possessor, and, similarly, a willingness by other countries that possess the relevant technology, to make that technology available for peaceful purposes. It is not a matter of being a soft touch; it is a matter of meeting the international obligations that the non-proliferation treaty places squarely upon us along with every other one of the international signatories to that treaty.

If you do not understand that, you do not understand the way in which the safeguard system operates. If you do not understand that, you do not understand what it is that has kept the world relatively free of nuclear weapons proliferation for the last generation. If you do not understand these dimensions of this subject, you should not be opening your mouth, Senator Kernot, in public because every time you do you make an idiot of yourself. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. I notice the minister recently launched a publication called Australia: your research and development location in Asia. The publication sets out many of the advantages of Australia as an R&D base compared with other countries. Although we all recognise Australia's excellence in science capabilities, could the minister comment on the commercial bottom line? How much would it cost for an international company to set up an R&D facility here as opposed to elsewhere in the region? Why should they choose Australia?

—This government has run a stunningly successful campaign to attract international companies to set up their regional headquarters in Australia. Since we kicked off that campaign in September 1993 about 160 international corporations have chosen Australia over other locations in this region for their regional headquarters. They have invested $1.7 billion in doing so and employed 5,500 Australians to staff their offices.

PARA.TAB: Based on that, we had an independent agency do a survey of Australia as a location for research and development. This country has a very high quality science and technology base and very high quality skills in science and technology, and can deliver a product much cheaper. The results of that survey show that if you take, for example, a research and development facility employing 30 people at an average cost in Australia of $2.4 million per year—that is, covering staff, industrial rental, equipment, consumable and administrative costs—and compared it with the cost of doing that R&D elsewhere, if it were in Japan it would cost $6.2 million, or 2 1/2 times as much; if it were in France, Hong Kong or Germany, it would cost twice as much; if it were in the USA or Singapore, it would cost 45 per cent more; if it were in the UK, Taiwan or South Korea, it would cost 25 per cent more.

That is just the cost comparison. When you add in the high quality research base that we have in our universities, in the CSIRO and other science institutions, and in the CRCs that we have successfully managed to establish under our government, as well as in private sector research and development, you have a critical mass here of a science community that can deliver a world class product on time, to quality, but substantially below the price.

The other reason for attracting international corporations to do that here is that we have very high quality laws to protect the intellectual property. It is no good discovering new ideas without being able to protect them. Australia has laws that do that. Additionally, we have a high quality telecommunications system in this country. In the two areas where it is vital for international communications to operate in this field—international calls and 64 kilobyte leased lines—of the 24 OECD countries, Australia leads the pack.

In addition to that, there is a trend for international corporations to come here anyway. Companies like Kodak, Kraft, Microsoft and Motorola from the USA, Glaxo Wellcome and Unilever from the UK, Fujitsu and Toshiba from Japan, Ericsson, Hoechst and Siemens from Europe are all located here and take advantage of our excellence in this field.

The publication that I released on behalf of my department on 7 September, Australia: your research and development location in Asia, will now be taken internationally. We will approach leading corporations in the world with big R&D budgets to allocate their budgets and the performance of their R&D in Australia close to the Asian market, to take advantage of our high-technology base and to bring an even greater critical mass to Australia. This will extend the opportunities for our scientists and our technicians and give us a chance to establish a critical mass, which will also work to pull through local developers of research and development and give them further opportunity, feeding into a bigger population of research and developers in Australia from all over the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —My supplementary question is: how does Australia's economic performance underpin our attractiveness as a location for research and development?

—We are a very stable political country in this region, and that is a major selling point. In addition, we have a very strong economy. We have heard that our economy is on a sustainable, strong growth path. It is underpinned by a high level of investment. It is underpinned by a high profit share. It is underpinned by increasing real wages and increasing household disposable income. We are looking at an economy which has all of the features compared to European, North American and Japanese economies. That is to say that, when compared to the economies of the OECD, it is one of the best performers in that pack. It is an economy, too, that has a commitment by its government to continue the process of reform to make it even more competitive. That is a major selling point in Europe and North America, because our zeal in being successfully able to manage the transition to a more open and competitive economy is universally recognised around the world as a model for other countries.

—My question is to the Minister for Family Services. I refer the minister to her media release in which she recommended that men should be given supermarket maps to encourage them to `get the groceries more'. Is the minister aware of the enormous outrage and offence that her statement has provoked across Australia? Is the minister still in favour of this ludicrous scheme? If not, will the minister apologise and have the decency to take responsibility for the press statement rather than backgrounding journalists that it was the fault of a staff member? Is this all your own work?

—I guess this question was pretty hard to anticipate! I have to say that I am very aware, as one journalist has said, of just what a hornets' nest this has stirred up, but I would like to put it in perspective.

PARA.TAB: My office was asked if I would care to comment about a proposal from Austria that we should legislate in this country for men to do more housework. My response to that was that it was a ridiculous suggestion, and I totally opposed it. What is important to recognise is that more and more Australian families—indeed most of them—sort out very well between them how housework will be divided. Many more men are doing chores that their parents or grandparents did not do, and women are also into non-traditional areas. It is entirely appropriate that it is sorted out within families, and the best way of managing them.

Those non-traditional areas include not only more child care and management of looking after kids at home, but also an increased participation in shopping. The figures show quite clearly that there is an increase in the number of hours that men spend shopping. I have to say, Senator, that that press release came out of my office, and you would have to say that it was an unfortunate choice of words.
Opposition senators—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, go on.

—Go on, yes, Senator Vanstone, I will go on. I have to say that, if any offence has been conveyed, I certainly do regret that offence. What I have to say is that the major issue is whether or not this government's policies are assisting families in the important business of working out how best to manage what they are doing—their main job of looking after the people in the family or their children. Our government policies are designed to assist families in that business—through our child care, Medicare or whatever those programs are. This government is committed to assisting families to get on with the business of doing that. It is not about interfering in those families to tell them how to sort out the division of labour.

PARA.TAB: I think it is important to know that this government is supporting the families in the choices of work that they are doing. We are not about interfering, Senator; we are about helping families get on with the business of what they are about.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest, Minister, that you have divided families. Why is it acceptable for you as a minister to treat men as though they are foolish and ignorant when you insist that others, such as child-care centre staff, treat both sexes without bias?

—Anyone would know that it is not my practice and it is not my intention to point out the differences or to make that kind of negative or put-down comment. As I say, if there was offence conveyed by that, I apologise for it. The reason that this was taken up was that a proposal from a man came into my office suggesting that this would be a very big help. You have no idea of how many other suggestions are around. I am not in the business of rejecting those proposals.
—A man! It is pathetic!

—It is not pathetic, Senator. If you knew what has been coming into my office, you would know. The main concern is that we recognise, as I said, the perspective here. The important criterion is that we are not about to interfere in families and tell them how to sort it out for themselves. They are doing it splendidly. Thousands of men do the shopping; thousands of women do it too.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the resolution on landmines which is part of the plan of action agreed at the recently completed United Nations World Conference on Women in Beijing and in particular to the clause relating to landmines which states that all nations `are urged to adopt at the earliest possible date . . . a moratorium on the export of anti-personnel landmines'. I ask: is this agreement an official Australian position, or is it just an agreement by the Australian delegation to the conference? Will the minister now concede that, contrary to the comments he made in response to Senator Bourne on 28 August in which he claimed `there is no prospect of achieving a total ban on all classes of landmines at this stage', the women's conference outcome proved that such an agreement is a realistic aim? Will the Australian government now be pushing in Geneva for a total ban on all landmines?

—I hate to have to advise Senator Margetts but there is a considerable distance between getting a resolution out of a conference like the Beijing women's conference and actually getting governments to sign up to the kind of treaty that would produce that particular result, particularly when at the moment there simply have been no humane and viable alternatives to landmines which have yet been developed and when you have the overwhelming number of defence forces around the world utterly unwilling to contemplate any change of that particular kind.

PARA.TAB: Under those circumstances and recognising that reality, what Australia has been really trying extremely hard to do, and with I think some present prospects of success, is to achieve what we think is a realistic objective; namely, to ban absolutely any anti-personnel landmines that are not self-destructing or self-neutralising in their character, thus removing, if we could achieve that result, what is overwhelmingly the problem about landmines at the moment, with them being sown indiscriminately, not subsequently gathered up, and creating ongoing tragedy potential as a result. If we can achieve bans of the kind that we are talking about and, accompanying that, a ban on the sale of landmines to any country around the world which does not commit itself to the Inhumane Weapons Convention and the kind of restrictions we are talking about, we will have made a phenomenal step forward.

This particular exercise in Beijing was subject to one or two misunderstandings along the way—I think by Senator Margetts. The particular stage of the conference at which this resolution was negotiated was a stage involving official delegations, not the non-government organisations, and as such it did represent input from governments as such—governments for the purpose of this conference. I can assure you, if there was any chance of some of those propositions extending more generally, as is the case in other areas, that is one thing, but I do not think there is much prospect, for reasons I have already mentioned, of extending them into the defence area. But let us hope that that might be achievable.

The instructions of the government to the delegation in this respect were to make known our reservations about certain aspects of the resolution as it was originally put, but under no circumstances to stand aside and to refuse to join a consensus. The exercise that was embarked upon by one rather enthusiastic delegate in moving an amendment and so on and throwing that part of the discussion into uncertainty at some stage was not an exercise that was mandated, directed, required or wanted by the government.

Finally, this government would be absolutely delighted if we could make landmines disappear from the face of the universe. The way in which they have been deployed in the past and the way in which they are continuing to be deployed right now creates the appalling potential for and the appalling reality of human tragedy. I have been to Cambodia. I have seen the number of people without limbs. I know of the way in which this tragedy is operating in so many other countries. I am working very hard, as is the government, to try to do something about it.

If we genuinely believe that an absolute ban on all forms of landmines was achievable and that there was some sort of viable and humane alternative that would meet the needs of defence forces for appropriate defensive weaponry, we would be the first country in the world to leap in and support that. But in the absence of that sort of available option at the moment, we are trying to work for a realistic objective which will solve overwhelmingly, if we can make that stick and make it work, about 99 per cent of the actual problem that exists at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Coulter this day, relating to methods of national accounting and a World Bank report on national net worth.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a well established practice in every business in this country and throughout the world that they keep at least two accounts: a capital account, in which they keep the value of buildings and equipment which they own, and a cash flow account. When a business sells off part of its capital equipment, it shows that as a transfer of wealth from the capital account to the cash flow account. That is standard accounting practice.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, this country shares with most other countries the failure to properly develop a national capital account. For example, when we chop down trees in a forest—they are capital assets; they are cash in the bank, as it were, which all people in Australia own—and we sell them off overseas as woodchips or as sawn timber, money appears in the cash flow account. However, because of our faulty accounting methods, we fail to show that what we have done is to simply transfer wealth from the capital account to the cash flow account.

So we can have a system, and we have had in this country for a long time, in which the country can appear to be becoming more and more wealthy when, in fact, it is simply running down the capital assets which the country as a whole owns—not just this generation, but all future generations as well—and showing that as a gain in wealth in its cash flow. Moreover, this government is not only doing that; it is frittering away that wealth that is derived from the exploitation of its capital assets and not re-establishing capital assets, but rather using it as immediate expenditure.

We find that the government is able to claim, as this government has done and, indeed, as Senator Gareth Evans has done on frequent occasions, and as he did today in answer to an earlier question by Senator Hill based on the same material—and I have to say that Senator Hill clearly misunderstands what the World Bank is on about—that the country is becoming better off because its GDP is increasing. There have been a number of studies done, not just the ABS study that Senator Evans handed to me earlier, which seek to sort this material far more comprehensively than the ABS—if I had time, I would comment on the inadequacy of this study—and which show that, since the mid-1970s, in country after country, even though the GDP as presently measured is increasing, when you start to take out those factors of decline in the capital asset base on which that growth is based, you find that countries are becoming worse off. These studies are being done in America and in the United Kingdom.

It accords with what average people feel, what they feel in their bones. They feel that there is something wrong when Mr Keating says, `You are better off. You have never had it so good. The country is becoming better off. You personally are better off.' Part of the reason is that we are seeing a steady decline in that capital base which is simply being turned into cash flow. The establishment of comprehensive national accounts is desperately needed, both in this country and in most other countries: a national capital account; a GDP account which disaggregates the costs from the benefits—and that is another major flaw; and an accounting system which looks specifically at human welfare and human wellbeing separately from simply the dollar value.

If I can just briefly mention one of the things in the report that Senator Evans handed me today. The ABS is making the mistake of discounting the future. This is one of the ways in which it is doing its accounting. Whenever you put a discount rate into the assessment of the future value of natural resources, you are effectively discounting the future, discounting the value to future generations of those natural resources—those forests and those minerals in the ground—which we possess. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: One point I wanted to put on the public record which tends to be overlooked by government spokespersons and by the media and economic commentators is Australia's international competitiveness, if you want to use that term—a comparison of our real interest rates. PARA.TAB: Under this government, that has not happened. It is extraordinary that Senator Evans should come in here saying, `Isn't it wonderful that we have this great innate natural wealth', and then try to take the credit for it when the facts are that under this government not even this high level of natural wealth can insulate Australians from the consequences of an incompetent government. That is what has happened over these 12 1/2 to 13 years of Labor administration.

It is despite the fact that we are naturally rich that we have had the recession we had to have and that we have had a million unemployed—that is, the million obvious unemployed, apart from the other million or so hidden unemployed. It is despite that natural wealth that so many Australians are struggling to pay off their homes, that there are still three-quarters of a million officially out of work, that young Australians have such a relatively low prospect of getting a job quickly, that we have a 25 per cent youth unemployment rate and that there are so many people—particularly in some of the dormitory suburbs, if you want to call them that, of the major metropolitan areas—including young couples who find that they owe more on their home than their home is now worth, because of a combination of factors.

It is despite this huge `wealth' that the government boasts about that we are going broke every year. Every month we have this massive balance of payments deficit that someone has to pay. It is all right for the government to say, `This is borrowing on private account.' The fact is that, as we go further and further into debt every year, there is a massive interest bill that the nation has to pay, and it is government policies that bring about this massive foreign debt, because there is a lack of domestic saving.

It is nonsense for the government to say, `Don't blame us; it is private sector borrowing.' That is absolute self-evident nonsense. What the World Bank figures are showing is that 12 1/2 years of Labor government has meant that our massive advantages—which should mean Australia's standard of living should be constantly increasing and that we should be a happier and wealthier country—have been steadily wasted. Our standards have deteriorated, with many people out of work and prospects for many poor. It is a scandal that, with this massive natural wealth, we should have been so decimated and our prospects so destroyed by this incompetent Labor government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.EMPHASIS: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO REPORT BY JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON THE NATIONAL CAPITAL AND EXTERNAL TERRITORIES ON ITS INQUIRY INTO KING GEORGE V MEMORIAL

SPEECH.PARA: Background
The proposal for the restoration of King George V Memorial in Canberra was referred to the Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital and External Territories on 2 March 1995.

The Committee's Report was tabled in Parliament on 29 May 1995. A comprehensive conservation and restoration program of works was proposed to the Committee which included the removal of two mature Lombardy poplars.

Under section 5 (1) of the Parliament Act 1974, the proposed removal of two mature Lombardy poplars will require Parliamentary approval. The Australian Heritage Commission has advised that "it appears that there is no prudent or feasible alternative to the removal of the two Lombardy poplars adjacent to King George V Memorial". Subject to Parliamentary approval for the removal of the trees, the restoration and conservation works will proceed during Spring 1995.
"The Committee recommends that the King George V Memorial remain on its present site as its permanent location."
Agreed.

"The Committee recommends that the required restoration of the King George V Memorial proceed on the basis that its current location is permanent and that restoration be completed to a standard commensurate with the permanent siting of the Memorial."
Agreed subject to budgetary constraints.

The conservation and restoration program proposed to the Committee by the National Capital Planning Authority (NCPA) involved costs of the order of $226,905. The NCPA has been allocated $305,000 for the 1995/96 financial year for the restoration of the Memorial. This funding will enable a substantial restoration and conservation program to be completed. While this will not be at the optimum range of restoration recommended by the Committee it will meet the immediate and long term conservation needs of the Memorial. It will also enable the Memorial to be made accessible to the public. Root barriers will be installed to limit future damage to the Memorial by the existing Lombardy poplars as well as the two to be planted to replace those recommended for removal. The maintenance schedule for the
Memorial, somewhat neglected in the past, will be reinstated and will address the long term needs of the Memorial.
"On the basis of Recommendations 1 and 2, the Committee recommends that the proposed removal of the two mature Lombardy poplars be approved."
Agreed.
As advised at Recommendation 2, available funding will allow the installation of root barriers which will limit future damage to the Memorial.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE PARLIAMENTARY JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY'S REPORT

SPEECH.PARA: 'INVESTIGATING COMPLAINTS MADE AGAINST
THE NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY'

The Report of the Parliamentary Joint Committee, on the investigation of complaints against the National Crime Authority or its staff, and which was tabled on 10 October 1994, follows on from the Committee's earlier evaluation, in 1991, which was entitled `Who is to Guard the Guards?—An Evaluation of the National Crime Authority'.

The current Report contains one recommendation only, that legislation be introduced as soon as practicable to provide for the establishment of an office of Inspector-General of the National Crime Authority to investigate complaints against the Authority or its staff, which essentially replicates a recommendation contained in the 1991 Report.

The recommendations of that Report were addressed by the Government through the National Crime Authority' Amendment Bill (No 2) 1992 (the Bill). In particular, the Bill provided for the establishment of an Office of Inspector-General to deal with complaints against the NCA and amended the Act to clarify the access of the Parliamentary Joint Committee to sensitive NCA information.

When the Bill was debated in Parliament the provisions relating to complaints were unanimously supported but a number of amendments to the access provisions were made in the Senate which were unacceptable both to the Government and to the State and Territory Ministers who are the Members of the Inter-Governmental Committee of the National Crime Authority. The amended Bill was therefore laid aside by the Attorney-General, Mr Duffy, on 16 December 1992.

The Government remains committed to ensuring the accountability of the National Crime Authority through an appropriate complaints regime. Circumstances have changed since the PJC reports of 1991 and 1994. The NCA now employs no non-police investigators. All NCA investigative staff are either members of the AFP or are seconded from State or Territory police services, and are thus subject to the formal complaints regimes of their respective jurisdictions

In recognition of these changes, and in order to accommodate concern expressed by the States that any complaints regime introduced for the NCA should mesh effectively with State arrangements, the Government has decided to give a reference to the Australian Law Reform Commission to inquire into the most appropriate means of handling complaints against the NCA, to be undertaken in conjunction with its current inquiry into the complaints and disciplinary system of the Australian Federal Police. The ALRC would be required to report by 30 June 1996. This position is supported by the Inter-Governmental Committee.
A copy of the ALRC reference is attached.

PARA.TAB: For its stance on testing, the Chinese government must receive the same amount of international pressure as has been applied to the French government. China needs to realise that, if it keeps testing, this will exacerbate independent struggles and ethno-political and economic tensions in its outlying autonomous regions. Testing will have the opposite effect and will encourage people to want to break free, as China is sacrificing their health, welfare and ecology for objectives that are illegal and unnecessary. If anyone doubts that logic, people in Tahiti felt exactly the same—that it was the testing that was exacerbating the call for self-determination in that region.

Australia's statements against China have been couched in our disappointment at China's testing just after the conclusion of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. China would be cynical about Australia's pro-active role during NPT negotiations where we helped nuclear weapons states to protect their existing arsenals from any definite timetable for disarmament. Although China is a nuclear weapons state, it is a nuclear weapons state trying to keep up with other nuclear weapons states. Disarmament is therefore crucial for Britain, the CIS and the US who have far more nuclear weapons than China could dream about, before we destroy any reason for China to test any more.

If we are to stop the nuclear arms race, then we must not stop at the physical testing of weapons but at the computer simulation testing of weapons that the US and the CIS employ which provide a reason for other nations to test in the first place. SPEECH.PARA: The Ozone Protection Amendment Bill 1995 will amend the Ozone Protection Act 1989 and repeal the Ozone Protection (Licence Fees-Manufacture) Act 1989 and the Ozone Protection (Licence Fees-Imports) Act 1989. The Ozone Protection (Licence Fees-Manufacture) Bill 1995 and the Ozone Protection (Licence Fees-Imports) Bill 1995 will replace the repealed Licence Fee Acts.

These Bills reflect Australia's evolving obligations under the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer and exemplify this Government's long standing commitment to the recovery of the earth's stratospheric ozone layer.

The Ozone Protection Amendment Bill will establish the legislative structure to enable Australia to implement effective controls on methyl bromide, hydrobromofluorocarbons (`HBFCs') and hydrochlorofluorocarbons (`HCFCs') similar to those controls under the current legislation on chlorofluorocarbons (`CFCs') and other ozone depleting substances. The Bill also repeals the current licence and quota system from 31 December 1995, consistent with Australia's obligations under the Montreal Protocol, to stop the further import or manufacture of CFCs, halon, methyl chloroform or carbon tetrachloride. The Bill provides for exemptions, where these are permitted under the Protocol, for essential uses such as medical dose inhalers and for used ozone depleting substances.

In 1989 when the Ozone Protection Act was originally passed, even the most optimistic forecasters could not have predicted that ozone benign technologies would be developed by industry and accepted by consumers in less than six years. Australia has effectively played its part in the global strategy to save the ozone layer. By the end of 1995 Australia will have phased-out the manufacture and importation of CFCs, halon, methyl chloroform and carbon tetrachloride. This is an enormous achievement and the Government recognises the efforts made by all levels of our society to date. Industry has proved that concerted, cohesive strategies do bear fruit and can succeed in reversing what was described in 1989 as one of the world's worst catastrophes.
But more needs to be done if we are to consolidate all the achievements to date.

In 1993 and 1994 the Antarctic ozone `holes' were the biggest and deepest on record. We can expect that ozone destruction will get worse before the reversing effects of the Montreal Protocol measures are evident in the stratosphere. The rate of ozone destruction is expected to peak during the next few years, then start to slow down during the early part of the 21st century. Based on these forecasts, and provided international action proceeds as planned, the ozone layer will be at its most damaged around the turn of the century and should recover in about fifty years' time. The trends are already good. Atmospheric growth rates in the troposphere of several major ozone-depleting substances have slowed. This is evidence that the Montreal Protocol is having its intended effect.
This is the scientific background against which recent amendments to the Montreal Protocol and the proposed amendments to the Ozone Protection Act must be viewed.

The amendments have been prepared in consultation with relevant Commonwealth departments, State and Territory environmental agencies, conservation and community organisations and affected industry sectors.

In April 1995 the Australia and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council (ANZECC) endorsed policies for HCFC controls. It was recognised that HCFCs would need to be used in Australia as temporary substitutes for CFCs—but only temporarily because these substances still are ozone depleting. As part of Australia's strategy for their phase-out, two different levels of controls were proposed by ANZECC. For controls on HCFC supply and production, Commonwealth legislation was recommended and for controls on emission and use, State and Territory legislation was recommended. ANZECC's decisions followed two years of discussion between representatives of the Commonwealth, State/Territory Governments, industry and conservation groups on the extent and types of controls necessary to meet Australia's needs. These polices followed on from the ANZECC's endorsement of the Revised Strategy for Ozone Protection which did not include HCFC or methyl bromide recommendations.

The Bills before the Senate are based on the policies agreed to by ANZECC, industry and conservation groups. State Governments have already, or are now, preparing complementary emission controls on HCFCs.
In summary, the Ozone Protection Amendment Bill:
provides that all current licences for CFCs, halon, methyl chloroform and carbon tetrachloride cease on 31 December 1995;
establishes a new system of essential use and used substances licences for ongoing uses allowed under the Montreal Protocol;
introduces a new system of controlled substances licences for HCFCs and methyl bromide;
bans HBFC exportation and manufacture; and
establishes a Trust Fund into which all fees will be paid to support the administration of the Act and management programs for HCFCs and methyl bromide.

Under the current Ozone Protection Act 1989, CFCs, halon, methyl chloroform and carbon tetrachloride have each been subject to a licensing system and a progressive phase-out. The phase-out of these substances will be complete at the end of this year. This will have been achieved through unprecedented co-operative efforts by governments, industry and the Australian community and has set a benchmark for collaboration on environmental protection in Australia.

The proposed amendments provide that the import, export and manufacture of CFCs, halon, methyl chloroform and carbon tetrachloride will be banned as of 1 January 1996, except in the limited circumstances allowed by the Montreal Protocol. These exceptions are accommodated under the Bill by two types of licences: an essential uses licence and a used substances licence. I will deal with each in turn.

In relation to the substances being phased out, the Montreal Protocol allows for continued use in a limited number of "essential use" applications. Australian "essential uses" have been approved for the years 1996 and 1997 by the Parties to the Protocol. This will allow for the continued import of CFCs for metered dose inhalers and substances for laboratory and analytical uses in those years. If CFCs are still required beyond 1997, a further application for `essential uses' will be made to the Protocol Parties.
"Essential use licences" for these uses will be issued subject to strict conditions and in accordance with the Protocol guidelines and definitions.

Turning to the proposed system of used substances licences, the Montreal Protocol distinguishes between new substances and recovered or recycled substances. Ozone depleting substances which have been recycled or reprocessed to the required purity specifications, or which are destined to be so recycled or reprocessed within Australia or overseas, may be imported or exported under a used substances licence. This type of licence will also be required for the import or export of waste ozone depleting substances. The used substances licence system will replace the current restricted licence system under the Act.
The licences will be subject to strict conditions specifying the permitted activity and the circumstances under which it may be carried out.

In addition to the phase out of CFCs, halon, methyl chloroform and carbon tetrachloride by the end of 1995, the Parties to the Montreal Protocol agreed in November 1992 to phase out the use of HBFCs by the end of 1995, to phase out HCFCs by the year 2030, and to freeze methyl bromide consumption from January 1995 at 1991 levels.

To enable Australia to ratify the 1992 Protocol amendments, the Ozone Protection (HCFC, HBFC and Methyl Bromide) Regulations 1993 were made. Under this Bill the provisions of these regulations are to be incorporated into the Ozone Protection Act. The regulations enabled controls on methyl bromide imports to commence under the Act from 1 January 1995 when controls on methyl bromide came into force internationally. In the case of HCFCs and HBFCs, controls will come into force internationally on 1 January 1996.

Consultation with industry and other interest groups concerning the extent and types of controls necessary to meet Australia's obligations revealed a preference by industry for a more flexible approach, involving a degree of self-regulation, compared with the system which was used for CFC phase-out.

Industry has co-operated with Commonwealth and State environment agencies to set an upper limit for production and importation in Australia which ensures that Australian use of these substances is constrained, while the interim status of HCFCs as substitutes for CFC equipment is recognised. Industry is confident that manufacturing and importation activity will stay under this limit, but accepts the need for government involvement if activity exceeds this limit. In contrast with the previous CFC licence and quota scheme, licences will be easier to obtain and transfer, and if government involvement through a quota system is necessary, quotas will be based on licensees' market activity.

The regulation of HCFCs and methyl bromide will be achieved under the Amendment Bill by a licensing scheme. A controlled substances licence will be necessary for the importation, export and manufacture of those substances.

HCFCs are used mainly for refrigeration and air conditioning. They are also used for foam manufacture and as aerosol propellants. In 1992, the Montreal Protocol Parties agreed to phase-out HCFCs totally by 2030, with a 90% phase-out being completed by 2015. In 1993, Australia used 2,573 tonnes of HCFCs. Australia has one manufacturer and approximately 11 importers of HCFCs. The manufacturer has already announced that it intends to close the plant in Sydney by the end of 1995.

The Amendment Bill establishes an initial limit on total consumption of HCFCs, called the Australian cap, which will gradually reduce until the current Protocol phase-out in 2030 is achieved. The cap will be made up of an industry limit and a reserve limit. For 1996, these limits will be 250 ozone depleting potential tonnes and 50 ozone depleting potential tonnes respectively. The industry limit is that quantity agreed by industry as being necessary to meet the needs of existing HCFC uses and CFC uses that may convert to HCFC. The reserve limit is an amount set aside for exceptional circumstances to ensure that essential type uses are not jeopardised by an Australian cap.

Licences will be issued for a two year period and will be more easily obtained than under the current CFC scheme which was based on prior activity. The new scheme will control the total amount of HCFCs imported or manufactured but will not limit the number of licensees. The CFC scheme, in comparison, limited the total number of licensees but did not limit the amount of CFCs that could be imported or manufactured to less than the Protocol limits.
This will allow companies wishing to participate in the HCFC market for only a short period the flexibility to enter and leave the market but will not increase the total amount of HCFCs being used.
Providing industry collectively imports or manufactures less than 90% of the industry limit on HCFCs, industry will self-regulate and the quota system will not be necessary.

If in any year this 90% limit is exceeded, quotas will be allocated to individual importers and manufacturers. If the 90% limit is exceeded the Minister will be required to give notice in the Gazette advising that from the next HCFC period the HCFC quota system will commence. The notice will establish the base year for quota allocation and the total amount to be issued through the quota system, based on the industry limit as stated for that year in the Act.

Once the quota system is triggered, it will be illegal to import or manufacture HCFCs without a licence and a quota. Quotas to individual licensees will be based on the market share of each licensee in the last full calendar year preceding the commencement of the quota period. Licences will be transferable on approval of the Minister and quotas will be fully transferable. If a company obtains a licence after the commencement of the first HCFC quota period, it will be up to that company to acquire a quota from existing licensees. Companies in this situation will be advised of this condition prior to any licence being issued.

Industry believes that the proposed Australian cap is realistic and adequately caters for increased use of HCFCs as temporary substitutes for CFCs from 1996 to 1999. To avoid the early retirement of expensive, commercial air conditioning equipment with a long economic life, a small quantity of HCFC quota will, under the current schedule, remain available until 2030.
A review of the scheme is proposed for the year 2000 to ensure that the scheme continues to meet Australia's requirements and Australia's obligations under the Montreal Protocol.

Methyl bromide is a fumigant used to kill pests and diseases in soil, stored grain and quarantined primary products. In 1992, the Montreal Protocol Parties agreed to restrict the import and manufacture of methyl bromide to 1991 levels as from 1 January 1995. Under the Protocol decision, quarantine and pre-shipment uses are exempted from the freeze.
Australia imported 1200 tonnes in 1994 and, as required by the Protocol, has limited its imports for 1995 to 688 tonnes for non-quarantine and pre-shipment purposes.

There is no single substance which can substitute for methyl bromide, given the wide range of applications for which it is used, but several alternatives are available for certain specific applications. At present no practical substitutes are known for a number of important applications, such as quarantine, however research into alternatives is proceeding in Australia and internationally.

Many agricultural sectors will be affected by methyl bromide restrictions. The main impacts are likely to occur in sectors which are required, under plant health standards, to have disease and pest free stock, particularly the strawberry growing industry and flowering bulb industry. These industry sectors and others which may be affected are involved in consultations with the Environment Protection Agency, with a view to each industry sector developing its own strategy for dealing with the management of methyl bromide and any further international controls. The co-ordination of research, information and training will all be important elements of Australia's overall strategy for reducing methyl bromide use.

Other countries which have already controlled or phased out methyl bromide, such as the Netherlands, have found suitable substitutes. The United States has announced a domestic ban on methyl bromide from the year 2001. Those countries that have already phased out claim to have found substitutes without major economic impacts.

The regulatory scheme proposed for methyl bromide has been kept as straightforward as possible because only two companies expect to continue importing. Under the Amendment Bill, methyl bromide importation will be continued under a controlled substances licence. A condition of the licence will set a maximum quantity of methyl bromide that can be imported annually by the licence holder. Each importer will be allocated a share of the total amount of methyl bromide that Australia is allowed in a particular year under the Montreal Protocol, based on their market activity. The licences will be issued every two years. The scheme allows for the Montreal Protocol targets to be reduced if possible, although this is not proposed at this early stage of methyl bromide controls.

The Amendment Bill will repeal the Ozone Protection (Licence Fees-Imports) Act 1989 and the Ozone Protection (Licence Fees-Manufacture) Act 1989 which will be replaced by the Ozone Protection (Licence Fees-Imports) Act 1995 and the Ozone Protection (Licence Fees-Manufacture) Act 1995. The new Acts will allow for non-refundable fees to be levied on the activity of licensees, based on the quantity and ozone depletion potential of HCFCs imported or manufactured and the amount of methyl bromide imported or manufactured. In addition, an application fee will be required. The fees will recover the costs of administering the licensing systems and fund HCFC and methyl bromide management and industry awareness programs.

The scheme is intended to be cost-neutral to the Commonwealth Government. Industry has agreed, based on its experience with the CFC licensing scheme, that the Commonwealth Government through the Environment Protection Agency, has an important information role in assisting owners of equipment with their decision to convert to alternative technologies, equipment and processes which have no impact on stratospheric ozone. Industry has also agreed that the awareness programs should be based on the principle that those companies deriving a benefit from the import or manufacture and use of ozone depleting substances should pay for the cost of programs designed to assist users of those substances to change their practices. Industry representatives have been consulted on the level of fees and have not objected to the proposals.

Consistent with those principles, industry supports the creation of a Trust Fund to ensure that revenue collected from licensees at the time of peak activity, between the year 1996 and the year 2000, can be spread and utilised at the times of lower activity between the years 2000 and 2030 when the need for information programs will be most critical if Australia is to minimise the economic impact of the final stages of the phase-out program.

Initial activity fee levels for HCFCs will be set at $2000 per ozone depleting tonne and for methyl bromide at $900 per tonne. The bases for calculation of fees will be set out in regulations. Importers have no objections to the level of fees. There will also be a two-yearly administration fee for each licence, which will be set at $10,000 per licence period until the year 2000. Fees for essential uses licences will be set at $2,000 per annum and for used substances licences at $10,000 per annum.

Australia has been at the forefront of international efforts to mitigate damage already done to the ozone layer and to minimise future damage. The Commonwealth Government's approach in building an effective partnership with industry to phase-out ozone depleting substances is proving to be an innovative and successful way of meeting the need for ozone protection while containing the effects on the wider community. These Bills will ensure that Australia continues not only to meet its international obligations under the Montreal Protocol, but to lead by example in protecting the ozone layer through innovative and effective regulation.
I commend the bills to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill contains a number of proposed amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 and the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984 which arise from the recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters in its report entitled "The 1993 Federal Election" which was tabled on 16 November 1994.

Some of the matters dealt with in the Committee's report which are of a minor or technical nature, and which require legislative amendment, have been taken up in the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1995 which was introduced in the House of Representatives on 1 February 1995.

This second bill will allow greater flexibility in the method used by the Australian Electoral Commission for the conduct of Electoral Roll Reviews. Rather than being required to undertake a full roll review every 2 years, the Commission may now conduct reviews targeted to areas of high population movement or lower than expected enrolment, instead of or as well as full national roll reviews. The Commission will also be able to conduct reviews using other methods in addition to the traditional visits to habitations.

The bill will allow electors who are going overseas to apply to register as eligible overseas electors within three months of their expected departure or within one year after the actual date of departure. At present electors who are going overseas must apply within one month of expected departure and, if they do not, they cannot apply once they have departed.
The bill will extend the time for the close of rolls from 6.00pm until 8.00pm on the day the rolls close for an election.
The bill will ensure that the death or withdrawal of a candidate, who is one of a number bulk nominated, will not invalidate the nomination of the remaining bulk nominated candidates.

The bill will allow for the dispatch of postal ballot materials to all registered General Postal Voters immediately after the declaration of nominations. Currently, only those General Postal Voters who are registered as unable to sign their name are sent postal ballot material directly. All other General Postal Voters are sent an application for a postal vote, with postal ballot materials sent only on the return of the application. This process can disenfranchise some people who rely on the post to exercise their right to vote, especially those in remote areas where the postal services are infrequent and sometimes unreliable.

The bill will make workable the administration of the existing provisions regarding prisoner disqualification. The existing provisions provide for disqualification based on the maximum sentence which could have been imposed. To be properly administered, this would require a detailed study of the indications from the sentencing judge of the indictments and the sentencing judge's decision. The cost of such procedures would be prohibitive. The bill provides that the disqualification be based on the actual sentence imposed.
Finally the bill will also make a number of amendments of a minor technical nature.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
