(b)at the reconvened meeting, a quorum is constituted by 25% of the registered members.

SPEECH.PARA: `(3) Where it would be unreasonable or impracticable for a meeting to be reconvened at or on the time, day or place referred to in subsection (1) or (2) (as the case may be), the Chairperson may specify another time, day or place, provided the time and day specified are not earlier than the seventh day after the failed meeting, and the place is at, or in the proximity of the place referred to in subsection (1) or (2).

`(4) A reference in subsection (1) or (2) to "the same manner" means the manner in which the annual general meeting would normally be convened, except that notice of the meeting is to be given at least 6 days before the day of the meeting provided for in subsection (1), (2) or (3) (as the case may be).
`(5) This section does not affect the operation of subsections 26(2) to (4).'.
"4D. Subsection 29(4):
Omit the subsection, substitute:

`(4) Subject to this Act, an executive member holds his or her office from the time at which he or she is declared to have been elected to the office at an annual general meeting until the time, at the first or second annual general meeting, as the case may be, after that meeting, at which a person is declared to have been elected to that office.'.".
This second amendment relates to the number of people required for quorums at an annual general meeting. The amendment contains a number of procedures. Part 26A(1) reads:
Where an annual general meeting fails because a quorum has not formed within 60 minutes of the notified time of the meeting:

PARA.TAB: (a) the Chairperson must reconvene the meeting in the same manner, for the same time, in the same place and for the same day of the following week . . .
(b) at the reconvened meeting, a quorum is constituted by 40% of the registered members.

SPEECH.PARA: If that does not work, it is reconvened in the same way and a quorum is constituted by 25 per cent of the registered members. In part (3) of the amendment, we see what happens the next time that does not happen.

PARA.TAB: We are all conscious of how hard it can be to get quorums according to the rules. We have built into this amendment a suitable number of safeguards for notification of those who are eligible to attend. All we can do is rely upon those who think the matter is important to attend and to honour their obligations, whatever they may think they are, to that particular council.

In this amendment, we also provide for a term of up to two years for the executive. As Senator Alston said, how do you decide what is the most appropriate place at which to fix the time limit? It has been argued to us that one year is not sufficient but that three years might give too much power to those who have been elected. In consultation with others, including the opposition and the government, we decided that two years is a reasonable compromise. We will be prepared to review this decision if it does not work.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will support this amendment. It is a fairly imaginative formula, but I suppose the proposition is that, the greater the period of notice that you have, the less need there is to insist that you have a greater number of people present. In other words, the more time available, presumably the more time people have to take account of the importance of it. If they therefore choose not to attend, then you can reduce the minimum requirement. We think that makes sense. I have not seen it done before, but maybe it is appropriate in some of our party—
—Branch meetings.
—Yes, indeed.

—They do not need them. They just ring them up and tell them what has been decided. We do require something like seven. So I suppose if you postponed the meeting three or four times you would be down to one or two, which sounds quite good. The two-year period, as Senator Kernot says, is essentially a compromise, but I think it draws the line in the right place.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to give Senator Alston a long explanation of the internecine workings of the Australian Labor Party—those that I understand. I know I will never understand those of the Liberal Party. But let me say that the amendment that Senator Kernot has moved does make good sense, and the government is happy to support it.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not aware that we were proceeding to this bill at this stage. I think the Greens have already missed an opportunity of presenting one of our amendments. That may well have been my oversight, but I was not aware that it was coming up. I would seek clarification as to which amendments have been passed and which ones are under consideration at the moment.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)—If you have the running sheet there—

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not.
—If we could get a running sheet to you, it would probably be easier.
—I am not sure if you were about to acquaint me of where we were on the running sheet.
—I was, then you seemed to be getting advice from both sides of the chamber.
—I am sure your's would clarify it even further.
—On the running sheet the Democrats' amendments Nos 1, 2 and 3 have been put and passed. That is where we are at the moment. They are amendments to schedule 1.

—I seek leave to speak to that, even though it is too late to amend it. I just want to put on the public record what the Greens feel about those amendments, because the Democrats' amendment No. 3 is in conflict with the Greens' amendment No. 2.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem, as the Greens see it, with these amendments to the act is that they do not go far enough in allowing the self-determination which we believe is appropriate. Subsection 7(3) of the act required the council to have ministerial approval before making payments in excess of $1,000. As I understand it, the chamber has just passed the amendment by the Democrats which increased that amount.

—To $100,000. However, the Greens feel that that still remains a paternalistic standard, because it basically says that this group of people has to account to the government for amounts of money which it has not obtained from the government. It is quite practical and possible that, if the Aboriginal land grant act is referring to money that comes from the government, it may be reasonable to accept the normal auditing of those accounts be subject to the same kinds of provisions of any government funding. Our understanding is that they fulfil those obligations each year in the normal course of their audit.

PARA.TAB: There is no reason other than paternalism for the council to have further limits placed upon its operations. It would not be contemplated for similar non-indigenous community bodies. So what we are basically talking about, and what the amendment moved by the Democrats retained, is an increase in the limit, but the mistrust that is clearly implied by this remains. It was the amendment of the Greens which was to remove that section entirely.

I just wish to put on the public record, realising that the amendment has been passed, that in no way did we support either $1,000 or $100,000 being a requirement of this body when it does not apply to government funding, but applies to any transaction which that body is involved with. My understanding is that they have been dealing with turnovers in the millions. It is unreasonable to expect them to have to go through yet more hoops simply because they are an Aboriginal group. So we want to register grave concern about it.
The second amendment which we were going to put really would empower the council to make by-laws under the act in relation to its functions required or permitted by the act.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not on that one.
—Aren't we? I think we are, because we are talking about your third amendment.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)—I might interpose here for a moment. There seems to be some confusion about whether amendments Nos 1, 2 and 3 were put and passed. That is what my interpretation was.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think we have done the amendment which deals with the by-laws, which is amendment No. 3.

—Can I assist Senator Chamarette by suggesting to her, as you have indicated, that Democrat amendments Nos 1, 2 and 3 have been passed. As I understand it, the Senate has given leave for Senator Chamarette to place on record her position in relation to her amendment No. 1. I think that is what you have done.
—No, Minister, there is some—
—That is what I thought you had done.
—There is some confusion about whether amendment No. 3 has been put and passed.
—No, it hasn't.
—I think Senator Kernot would agree that amendments Nos 1 and 2 have been put and passed, but not No. 3 yet.
—Yes. In amendment No. 2 I referred to subsection (3), but I have not moved amendment No. 3. I seek leave to respond to a couple of those points.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Certainly, we discussed with the community the proportion of funding they deal with at the moment which originates from the government and the proportion of funding which in the future will be generated by successful economic enterprises. We certainly looked at the possibility of making a distinction between those two sources of funding some time in the future.

PARA.TAB: But, as they have not yet reached the stage where the majority of their funding comes from successful economic enterprises—we have not even finished giving them these rights yet—I think it is appropriate that we set the limit, as we did, at $100,000. As I said, we are prepared to review it and look at alternatives somewhere down the track.

I would say to Senator Chamarette, through you, Mr Temporary Chairman, that when we talk about self-determination, we cannot be too selective. Why is it okay for the Wreck Bay Aboriginal community to make these decisions and it is not okay for ATSIC? There is an inconsistency there. Self-determination is self-determination.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's not government funding we are talking about.
—It is government funds we are talking about. It ultimately will not be in the majority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —To respond to Senator Kernot, through you, Mr Temporary Chairman, the implication of the amendment she put forward that has been passed is that the Wreck Bay community will be accountable for any transaction of that amount, whether it is government funded or not. My understanding from discussions with members of the community is that they are already handling larger amounts of money that do not come from public funding but come through subscriptions via the national park mechanisms. They do not represent the government funding that is represented when ATSIC allocates $100,000, so there is a distinction. In my view, there is no justification for putting to this community an additional hoop that would not be there with any other non-indigenous community.
—But it is there with other non-indigenous communities. It is there, I gave the example earlier.

—For the record, I acknowledge that Senator Kernot is telling me that earlier she gave an example of non-indigenous organisations that have to be accountable for their funding amount by amount. I was not present so I did not hear that, but I still maintain that it is an unreasonable requirement that is being retained in the act. It is an anachronism, so that is why the Greens were proposing to drop that cap entirely as a way of giving appropriate self-determination to this community for the money with which they are dealing, without exempting in any way that community from the due auditing and accountability for the way in which they spend their money.

PARA.TAB: I believe that it is an important principle. I regret that it has not been clear to those who supported the amendment that there is a differing interpretation here. My understanding is that we are putting an unnecessary constraint on the community, even just by increasing the amount rather than eliminating it.

Further to moving on through the committee stage, my understanding is that Greens amendment No. 2 is actually contradictory to Democrat amendment No. 3, and I would seek to present our amendment No. 2 before Democrat amendment No. 3. I now move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Schedule 1, page 3, after item 2, insert the following item:
"2A. Subsection 7(3):
Omit the subsection.".

The Greens' first amendment deals with clauses 2A and 2C. The proposal is that we delete the words `in consultation with the minister'. In relation to clause 2C, we believe there should not be that amount. We would like to see subsection 7(3) of the act, which refers to ministerial approval before making payments in excess of $1,000, deleted completely on the basis of the comments I made earlier, which are that it is putting an additional requirement on this community that, in our view, should not be there and should be removed in its entirety.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before Senator Chamarette joined this debate, I did indicate that the government would support the amendment of the Democrats, which has been carried. There is a continuing need to maintain a level of accountability in relation to the councils entering into major contracts. I do not think the requirement to obtain ministerial consent is an onerous administrative burden, but I think it is a positive and useful procedural step as it provides an avenue for the council to enlist the assistance of ATSIC in obtaining advice in relation to major contracts.

PARA.TAB: The great majority of regular contracts, of amounts of less than $100,000, can be administered without ministerial consent. I think the Democrat amendment that has been carried does bring the Wreck Bay act into line with the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976, which has contained a similar provision since its inception in 1977. As far as I am aware, the four Northern Territory land councils have not experienced any administrative difficulty with that provision. Certainly, to my knowledge there has been no move to seek its deletion. Having already made a brief contribution at the time Senator Kernot moved her amendments, I think it is appropriate to place just those few brief words on record and indicate that the government will be opposing the amendment moved by Senator Chamarette.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask for the minister's clarification on the point made by Senator Kernot that there are other organisations on which this kind of constraint or requirement is placed that are non-indigenous. I think it is clear from the minister's comments just now that the precedent he is referring to is the one of the Northern Territory land rights act. While I understand that that is a correct position, I do not think it necessarily justifies the basis.

PARA.TAB: I ask the minister: is it the fact that it is an indigenous community and there is a desire by the government to check up on the economic activity of that indigenous community that is the rationale for inserting the requirement for consultation with the minister prior to any transaction of $100,000 taking place? My understanding is that that is a discriminatory rationale. It is on that basis that we are proposing it be dropped from the bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only say in response to Senator Chamarette that it is certainly the case with a number of my portfolio agencies, for example the Australian Nature Conservation Agency and the Australian Heritage Commission, that such ministerial consent is required.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Kernot for giving me the right to at least place this amendment. It is in conflict with the Democrats' amendment No. 3. It is unlikely to be supported; nevertheless, I will place it on the record and if it gains support, fine. If I had not been given this opportunity to move the amendment now, I would not have been able to place it on the record after Senator Kernot's amendment No. 3 is dealt with.

PARA.TAB: The amendment the Greens are moving at this point is one which empowers the council to make by-laws under the act in relation to its functions required or permitted by the act. The by-laws must be consistent with the laws of the Commonwealth and the Australian Capital Territory and would be disallowable instruments. The Greens' amendment would allow the council a measure of control over its own affairs and the proper carrying out of its functions. There is a clear process of accountability for the making of these by-laws.

The Democrats' amendment would specify the areas in which the council can make decisions and is an improvement, no doubt, on the government's bill. However, it again displays a mistrust for the unequivocal granting of autonomy to Aboriginal organisations to manage their own affairs. Why should we be more prescriptive about the way Aboriginal organisations operate than we are about others? I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Schedule 1, page 5, after item 8, insert the following item:
"9.After section 52:

TAB.TAB: Insert:

SPEECH.PARA: 52A.(1)Subject to subsection (2), the Council may make such by-laws in relation to its functions under this Act, as are:

TAB.TAB: (a)required or permitted by this Act to be made; or
(b)necessary or convenient to be made for carrying out or giving effect to its functions under this Act.

PARA.TAB: `(2) By-laws made under this section must not be inconsistent with any law of the Commonwealth or of the Australian Capital Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: `(3) By-laws are disallowable instruments for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.'.".

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I make what is probably a lawyer's point. If you take this Greens amendment at face value, what it actually says is that the council may make such by-laws as are required or permitted by this act to be made, or necessary or convenient to be made. In other words, you do not have to satisfy subparagraph (a). You can have by-laws that were not permitted or, indeed, even specifically prohibited. Nonetheless, on a reading of this you would be able to do whatever you thought was `necessary or convenient'. That seems to me to be a classic example of a Henry VIII clause, which would allow the regulations to, in effect, change the law as it stood. That, of course, is the very antithesis of delegated legislation. As it is drafted, certainly it seems to me to be far too broad and I do not see why the normal rules of interpretation should not apply here as they apply everywhere else.

—Far be it from me to say that I have any legal expertise and background but, just as an ordinary lay person reading this, it is quite clear that Senator Alston has not understood the amendment as put. There is nothing within this amendment relating to the setting up of by-laws which would allow the council to make any by-laws that would violate any law of the Commonwealth or the Australian Capital Territory or that would violate the functions under the act. That is quite clear.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, the amendment says that the council may make by-laws in relation to its functions under the act as are required and permitted by the act, or as are necessary and convenient to be made for carrying out or giving effect to its functions under the act. So there is no sense in which it is—what was the term, Senator Alston?

TALK.START.PARA: —Henry VIII clause.

—A Henry VIII clause. It is not by any possible categorisation a Henry VIII clause in my understanding. I certainly will ask the minister to clarify this. My understanding is that it simply will enable the council to perform whatever is its legitimate right under this act such that it is not inconsistent with any other law of the Commonwealth or of the Australian Capital Territory. It will allow it to be a disallowable instrument, so it will also be subject to the scrutiny of parliament. I think it is outrageous to say that this is a way in which we give people an unbridled right. It is simply a legitimate right and my understanding is that, if we do not give it, we are actually reducing the kind of autonomy that would be available to any other council making its own by-laws.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —In case I am either misunderstood or not making myself clear, can I say that subclauses (1), (2) and (3) stand alone. We do not need to concern ourselves with subclauses (2) or (3) for the purpose of determining what is meant by subclause (1). My point is simply this: if you have to satisfy only paragraph (a) or (b), then you logically have a situation where something is not permitted by the act but you would be able to make those by-laws in any event because they satisfy (b); in other words, they were necessary or convenient—
—For the carrying out.

—Indeed. But the logic of it is that you could fail to satisfy (a). You have to satisfy only one or the other; it does not say both. So you could make those by-laws as long as they satisfy (b) even if they were contrary to (a). In other words, if they were not permitted or required by the act, you could still make them as long as they were necessary or convenient.

PARA.TAB: That is simply a way of avoiding the power that is given in the first instance. The act usually says you can make by-laws with respect to X, or it may go on and say you cannot make by-laws with respect to X. What you are saying, Senator Chamarette, is that you can ignore that as long as it is necessary or convenient. You can get into endless arguments about what might be regarded by the mover as necessary or convenient; it is a highly subjective test. In any event, the logic of it is to say that it is not necessary for it to be required or permitted or indeed that it might be specifically not permitted, and yet you could still go ahead and enact those by-laws under (b).

I hope that Senator Chamarette will obtain some formal advice as to the effect of that provision. All I am saying is that, as I read it, it is not only far too wide but would inevitably be struck down, and for that reason we would not support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would again like to clarify the objection Senator Alston has raised. He is quite at liberty not to support the amendment, but it is outrageous that he is implying that there is some kind of logic to his argument that relates to subclause (1) and the fact that paragraphs (a) and (b) have a conjunctive `or' between them. These are the words of standard regulation making power in acts and they do not, without more words, constitute a Henry VIII clause. That would need an express power to override the act.

PARA.TAB: The two paragraphs relate to creating by-laws in relation to functions under the act. The first one relates to those that might be required or permitted by the act and they are obviously by-laws that will need to be carried out or additional by-laws which may be necessary or convenient to be made for carrying out or giving effect to functions under the act. So it is clearly in subjection to the act and I think it is very deceptive of Senator Alston to read out only half the sentence that relates to paragraph (b) of our amendment. I can only repeat that there is no way in which his criticism has a logic which is able to be applied to the phrasing of the amendment.

I am open to having another person who can explain the situation in a different way challenge me and say that the clause might need an `and/or' or something like that added, but I fail to see that it is necessary in any form. I think the way (b) is phrased makes it quite clear that by-law making cannot go beyond the powers of the act. For it to do so would require an express power to be written in somewhere, and nowhere is that written in.

I am very sorry that the legitimate standard regulations that apply for by-law making in relation to all acts are not being supported by the opposition and that the opposition is supporting a discriminatory basis whereby this council will be limited in the degree of its autonomy and its capacity to make its own by-laws under the act. That is where the Greens stand. I will not prolong these discussions, although it might be interesting to hear from the minister. In my view, Senator Faulkner shares the erroneous view that this in some way goes beyond the act. I have a clear understanding from my advice that that is not correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senator Alston. With respect, I must say to Senator Chamarette that I do not think she understands the ramifications of the proposed amendment. Let me try to elucidate the situation. What you have in paragraph (a) is a limitation on the scope of by-laws. It says that you can make by-laws only if they are `required or permitted', so there has to be a specific delegation within the act to enable a by-law to be made under paragraph (a). The problem is that paragraph (b) circumvents paragraph (a), because you could create a by-law under paragraph (b) which does not deal with a delegation specifically inserted in the bill.

PARA.TAB: I will give a hypothetical situation. Suppose one had an act which contained this provision and dealt with local government by-laws. The act said that the local government could by law declare any area a construction site and, by declaring that area a construction site, people would be obliged to meet certain workplace health and safety obligations. That would fit into paragraph (a).

But suppose the council decided that what it was going to do was not only designate a certain area a construction site but, by another by-law which was not specifically provided for under the act, also regulate the speed at which traffic passed on the streets surrounding the construction site. Because there is no specific delegation of that authority, the making of that by-law could not fall under paragraph (a). However, the council in question could say that it could make such a by-law because it was necessary or convenient for the carrying out of the construction that was to be embarked upon. That is the problem. Paragraph (b) adds a whole range of additional powers which are not specifically delegated in the legislation.

I will turn very briefly to the other argument that Senator Chamarette put up—that these by-laws were disallowable instruments. Senator Colston, as the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, you would understand that sometimes the making of a regulation can be detrimental and the disallowance of a regulation can be even more detrimental, because it precludes for a period of six months the making of a further delegated instrument which deals with the same subject matter which has been disallowed.

I think Senator Chamarette really misses the point if she says that these are disallowable instruments. I agree with Senator Alston—the scope which is permitted by paragraph (b) is too broad. That is why the coalition is not supporting the amendment, not because we have a discrimination towards Aborigines. It is just simply good law making.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Briefly, in response to Senator Chamarette's arguments—and I do not, I can assure you, Senator Chamarette, want to prolong this debate—my own view is that there is danger in the amendment that you are proposing for there to be no proper or appropriate limitation on the range of the by-law making power being granted. For example, linking this power to the functions of the council raises the possibility of creating by-laws in the areas of health, education, housing and so forth. That clearly would be inappropriate and confusing for their administration. It is for these reasons that the government, as I have indicated, will not be supporting the amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3.At end of schedule 1, page 5, add the following item:
"9A. After section 52:
Insert:
`52A.(1) In this section "Aboriginal Land" does not include land declared under section 9A.
`(2) The Council may make by-laws for or with respect to:

TAB.TAB: (a)economic enterprise on Aboriginal Land;
(b)cultural activities on Aboriginal Land;
(c)the management, access, conservation, fire protection, development and use of Aboriginal Land;
(d)the declaration of sacred or significant sites or other areas of significance to Aboriginal people on Aboriginal Land;
(e)the activities to be permitted on Aboriginal Land or any part of it;
(f)protection and conservation of flora or fauna found on Aboriginal Land;
(g)in relation to Aboriginal Land, the cutting, removal and sale of timber, the granting of revocable licences and the payment of royalties for timber to the Council;
(h)hunting, shooting and fishing on Aboriginal Land;
(i)control of visitors in, and charging fees (to be paid to the Council) for entrance to, Aboriginal Land;
(j)the regulation and control of motor traffic and parking on Aboriginal Land;
(k)the appointment of persons to enforce the by-laws, and the powers and duties of those persons.

SPEECH.PARA: `(3) The by-laws may apply any regulation made under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 to Aboriginal Land, with whatever changes are needed for that purpose.
`(4) A by-law, in applying a regulation referred to in subsection (3) relating to an offence, must not change the penalty for that offence.

`(5) A by-law must not be inconsistent with a law of the Commonwealth or a law in force in the Territory, but a regulation referred to in subsection (3) may, in its application to Aboriginal Land, be inconsistent with a law in force in the Territory.
`(6) The by-laws may provide that a contravention of a by-law is an offence.

(b)if the offender is a corporation—a fine not exceeding 25 penalty units.

SPEECH.PARA: `(8) The regulations may make provision for and in relation to enabling a person who is alleged to have committed an offence against the by-laws to pay to the Commonwealth, as an alternative to prosecution, a penalty not exceeding:

TAB.TAB: (a)in the case of a natural person—1 penalty unit; or
(b)in the case of a corporation—5 penalty units.

SPEECH.PARA: `(9) Subsections (7) and (8) do not apply in relation to an offence against a regulation referred to in subsection (3) in its application to Aboriginal Land.
`(10) If the Council makes a by-law, it shall, within 7 days after making it, give a copy of the by-law to the Minister.
`(11) Where the Minister receives a copy of any by-laws, the Minister shall:
(a)cause the by-laws to be notified in the Gazette; and

TAB.TAB: (b)cause a copy of the by-laws to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after receipt by the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: `(12) By-laws take effect from the day on which they are notified in the Gazette, or, where a later date is specified in the by-laws, from that later date.

`(13) If a copy of any by-laws is not laid before a House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after receipt by the Minister, the by-laws cease to have effect at the end of that period.

`(14) Where a copy of a by-law has been laid before a House of the Parliament under this section, the provisions of section 48 (other than subsections (1), (2) and (3)) and sections 48A, 48B, 49 and 50 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 apply in relation to the by-laws as if, in those provisions, references to regulations were references to by-laws and references to repeal were references to revocation.'.".

We have had a wide-ranging discussion on the making of by-laws. Again, it is not a matter of mistrust; it is a matter of commonsense. This has not been done without consultation with the community, which also acknowledge that there are some reasonable restraints applied to them because of existing acts, for example, the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act.

PARA.TAB: Under our amendment, we are giving power to the council to act similarly to a local government council. I think that is a sensible analogy to use. It is a sensible comparative model in my view. We acknowledge that this community council needs to make law with respect to economic enterprises, cultural activities, sacred sites, environmental protection, et cetera. Under this amendment we also give the council the ability to fine offenders against these by-laws.

I thought it was interesting to look at the huge number of functions that are conferred via the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 on wardens, rangers and wildlife inspectors. They are very wide ranging. There are 27 of them on the list I have here. In discussions with the community, I cannot foresee where we are preventing the community from being able to carry out the necessary functions that they have described to us under by-laws.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1995. The coalition will be supporting this bill. The aim of the bill is to improve import and export regulatory controls, ensuring the long-term conservation of native wildlife consistent with Australia's international obligations under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Flora and Fauna, CITES, and the International Convention on Biological Diversity. Australia ratified CITES in 1976 and ratified the convention on biological diversity in 1993.

PARA.TAB: The Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act, which is the principal act, was enacted in 1982 under the Fraser government. On 6 May 1982, the then Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, the Hon. Ian Wilson, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this bill is to strengthen arrangements for the protection of Australia's animals and plants, and world wildlife generally by improving the effectiveness of our import and export controls.

The act establishes a scheme to regulate trade in endangered species consistent with Australia's international obligations, including CITES. The act also provides the foundation for controlling trade in Australian native flora and fauna. On 12 March 1986, the then Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, the Hon. Barry Cohen, said:
The Act is a major element of the Government's nature conservation program. It received the support of all parties when introduced into Parliament in 1982.

The object of the act is to ensure that trade in fauna and flora is conducted in a sustainable manner. According to the Australian Nature Conservation Agency annual report in 1993-94, which I think summarised it quite well, the act plays an important role in preventing the establishment of pests and diseases which could adversely affect the Australian environment, by regulating the import of most species of live animals.

PARA.TAB: CITES recognises that international cooperation is essential for the protection of certain species of wild fauna and flora against over-exploitation through international trade. CITES aims to regulate the international trade in endangered species to ensure the survival of such species. It imposes different obligations on state parties, depending on the danger of extinction faced by the particular species.

The most recent conference of the parties on CITES was held in Florida in November last year. This was the ninth meeting of the conference. One hundred and nineteen parties attended the conference, which I understand is a record number, and presumably Senator Faulkner was there on behalf of Australia.

Important steps were taken at the conference to preserve some endangered species. For example, the main tiger bone producing and consuming countries put forward a resolution at the conference urging parties to adopt or strengthen legislation regulating the killing of tigers. The Republic of Korea has prohibited the sale of tiger bone from November 1994. It is estimated that there are less than 5,000 tigers worldwide. The conference will meet next in Zimbabwe in June 1997.

The convention on biological diversity defines biological diversity as `the variability among living organisms from all sources, including inter alia, terrestrial, marine and other aquatic ecosystems and ecological complexes of which they are part; this includes diversity within species, between species and of ecosystems'. Section 78 of the act requires appropriate consultation with state and territory ministers.

As Senator Faulkner mentioned in his second reading address, the proposed amendments to the bill have been developed after extensive consultations with state and territory governments, industry and non-government organisations and are in accord with the intergovernmental agreement on the environment. This is not to say that every aspect of the bill has universal support and acceptance, but I think it is true to say that the broad thrust of the bill is, in fact, widely supported.

There are a number of issues which various states, industry and conservation groups have raised with me, and I will be exploring these matters in the committee stage of the bill. For example, one issue which has received a high degree of interest in recent weeks has been the national registration scheme for exotic birds. In its discussion paper on the registration of exotic birds, published in June 1994, the Australian Nature Conservation Agency noted that the `illegal importation of exotic birds has increased dramatically over the past few years' and that existing legislative controls are inadequate.

The bill aims to safeguard the Australian environment from the illegal introduction of exotic birds by introducing a national registration system for certain species. The explanatory memorandum states that `the registration scheme will make it extremely difficult to trade in illegally imported birds'. The bill provides that after the transitional period—30 days after the section commences—a person cannot possess a classified exotic bird unless that person holds a registration certificate.

There will also be an exotic birds committee, which will provide an advisory group to the minister to examine the ongoing effectiveness of the registration scheme. The committee will comprise government, conservation, and private and professional aviculture representatives.

There have been some concerns relating to the registration of exotic birds. There have been a variety of views put to me, and I dare say to the minister as well, by groups such as the Associated Birdkeepers and Traders and the Avicultural Federation of Australia. I shall be raising with the minister some of the concerns which have been expressed to me, and I hope that these concerns can be effectively addressed in his responses.

Some aviculturists have alleged a lack of consultation about their concerns. Other groups such as the Queensland Birdbreeders Alliance and Associated Birdkeepers and Traders have strongly supported the amendment and argued that there has been consultation.

Mr Ian Woolcock of the Avicultural Federation of Australia has written to me—I dare say he has written to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) as well—and asked that a number of issues be raised during the debate. I understand that the minister has a copy of Mr Woolcock's letter and will undoubtedly respond to these concerns during the debate this afternoon.

Some of the issues raised by aviculturalists include the composition of the Exotic Birds Committee; what species are to be included and the rationale for their inclusion; how the scheme will work with existing state laws and regulations; how the scheme is to be funded; who will bear the costs; what ongoing input will be available to bird keepers of Australia; and what review mechanisms will enable species to be removed from the scheme. Among other things, the federation has expressed concerns over what they see as excessive penalties for possessing an unregistered bird and have asked for an assurance that no bird keeper will be required to pay more than one registration fee for the birds they keep.

In relation to the attitudes of state governments, one state has criticised what it sees as the artificial imposition of a five-year time limit on management program approvals and automatic suspension of approval of management programs with unrestricted approval time limits.In terms of the section referring to the zoological export of live animals, it has been pointed out that proposed paragraph 13(1)(e) proposes that animals must come from a species that can be readily bred in captivity. Some have asked how one can assess whether an animal can be readily bred in captivity and/or is difficult to breed in captivity. The states have also expressed concerns about the costs to states and territories of being expected to assist in implementing schemes such as the exotic bird registration scheme and the assistance which may be available by state and territory bodies in enforcing the act.

As one may expect, the Worldwide Fund for Nature has taken a keen interest in this bill, as has their associated organisation Traffic Oceania. They have made a number of proposals for amendments to this bill. I understand that some amendments will be moved. It is possible that the minister, in some of his remarks, will address their concerns.

I personally am very mindful of the fact that this is a complex bill and consultation is required with states and territories before major amendments can be made. I certainly give assurances to the Worldwide Fund for Nature and other interested groups that, if at the end of this debate they feel their concerns have not been effectively addressed, with the change of government, which is racing upon us and which will undoubtedly occur within a short period—maybe after Christmas—I, as the new minister for the environment, would hope to ensure that those outstanding concerns which have been raised by interested groups in this bill can be effectively considered with proper consultation with all groups.

There has also been a suggestion that the legislation is largely powerless to prevent the introduction of potential weeds into Australia and it does not require one to consider the possible environmental impact of the export of Australian plants.

The minister would certainly be aware of the paper Of tiger treatments and rhino remedies. Traffic Oceania has pointed out that poaching for illegal trade is driving the tiger and rhinoceros to the brink of extinction, parts of these species being used as ingredients in traditional Chinese medicine. Traffic Oceania believes that the Wildlife Protection Act and the amendment bill do not adequately cover manufactured items such as the traditional Chinese medicines or ivory inlaid items which contain CITES-listed species as an ingredient or a component. While in practice such items have been treated as falling under the provisions of the Wildlife Protection Act, the definition is said by Traffic Oceania to require clarification.

There is also the belief that the bill needs strengthening to properly implement the provisions of CITES resolution 9.6 on trade in readily recognisable parts and derivatives. This provision agrees that CITES provisions should:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . include any specimen which appears from an accompanying document, packaging or a mark or label, or from any other circumstances, to be a part or derivative of an animal or plant of a species included in the (CITES) appendices, unless such a plant or derivative is specifically exempted from the provisions of the Convention.

As I said, the bill enjoys fairly widespread support. There have been expressions of concern from some of the states and territories about particular provisions. Groups have followed this bill closely—groups like the Worldwide Fund for Nature, which has carried out intensive research, and their associate organisations such as Traffic Oceania, which would like to see the bill go further in a number of areas.

PARA.TAB: As I said, we look forward to the debate in the committee stage to see how the minister will address some of the concerns which have been raised. The coalition will support this important bill. Hopefully, some of the issues which have been raised can be dealt with during the committee debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with some interest to Senator Kemp's speech, particularly where he mentioned that he might be the next minister for the environment. I have to say that, when I looked through the Hansard at the time he was appointed to his august position, I found that the only references he made to the environment were to the economic environment and he made none whatsoever about the natural environment. With that sort of record I hope that, if the opposition does form the next government, he shall not be the minister for the environment because he has certainly not convinced me that he has an enduring interest in, concern for, knowledge of or anything else to do with the environment.

PARA.TAB: In second reading contributions it is usual to range fairly widely to set a bill in context. While it is usually my colleague Senator Woodley who deals with biblical references, I would like to start with Noah and the Ark. As somebody who is now a non-believer, I find it very difficult to think of 30 million species being taken on board two by two and then let go after the flood to re-populate the world. Nonetheless, I think there is a symbolism in that which is important to pick up in respect of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill: whether we like it or not, we have achieved a situation, because of our dominance of the natural environment, where we are now the caretakers of life on earth between now and whenever the end of life on earth will occur—perhaps 500 million years hence, when the sun cools, explodes or whatever.

Rejecting the conventional Christian view that there was ever any intention that homo sapiens would become the dominant and ultimate pinnacle of an evolutionary process, again paradoxically we have nonetheless assumed that situation. We have an awful—I use that word in its original biblical sense—responsibility with respect to caring for wildlife on earth at present. We now have, for instance, a population on earth of almost six billion people, and the population is expected to double before it asymptotes to some sort of plateau. This is assuming that we can find the resources—the food, the water and everything else to sustain such a large population. I observe that 40 per cent—this figure comes from the World Bank, an interesting body that has come out with some remarkable statements in recent times—of all the photosynthetic energy which falls on earth at present directly or indirectly flows through human civilisation.

One wonders what that means in terms of wildlife and natural ecosystem protection if the population is going to double and at the same time governments around the world are, like our government, bent on economic growth. Economic growth means that the percentage of natural resources consumed, including that proportion of photosynthetic activity, will increase. Indeed, the prospect looks extremely dim that within a doubling of population there will be any wildlife left on earth at all. That raises again the issue of whether humans can survive such a situation.

Contrary to what governments tell us—this government no less than any others—the economic system is not the dominant system into which the environment has to be fitted as an afterthought, if and when it can be fitted in. The environmental system, the natural environment, is the basis upon which the economy and every other aspect of human life rests. If we ignore that simple fact, we certainly do it at our peril. We do it at even greater peril to our children and their descendants.

Simon Crean and the Treasurer quite recently talked about sustainable economic growth rates of three per cent. How often have I pointed out that sustainable economic growth is an oxymoron. It is quite impossible to sustain economic growth because by its very nature it means increasing consumption of natural resources. It means an increase in the dollar value—in constant dollars, having taken out the inflation factor, one year compared with the previous year—at the cost of further consumption of the natural environment, the destruction of wilderness and loss of biodiversity.

Economic growth is simply not sustainable. Economic growth must plateau, as must human population, if there is to be any natural environment remaining for our children not just to enjoy but on which to form the substrate upon which their lives, their economies, their systems of survival will ultimately depend.

Setting this bill in its broadest context, it is a step in the right direction but it is only one small step and does not go nearly far enough. I am not criticising the bill or, in this respect the minister; I am criticising the whole context in which this government is operating. The context is wrong. The context indicates that this is simply not going far enough.

The view that I have put is often described as an alternative view. Again, that is quite wrong. It is not an alternative view. The conventional wisdom is not wisdom at all; it is stupidity. The idea that we can continue to grow and continue to consume the natural environment at three per cent per year compound interest is stupid.

The view that I am putting, that sooner or later, and preferably sooner, we must move towards a steady state—one in which there is no economic growth, one in which we set limits to the demands we make on the environment—that system is the only system which is sustainable in the long term. That is the biological view. That is the view that recognises that the world is finite; it is not infinite. The economic rationalists who believe in the growth paradigm are wrong.

Economic rationalists are like the robber of old, Procrustes, who, in order to make his victims fit onto a bed, cut them if they were too big or stretched them if they were too small. Economic rationalists behave in that same procrustean manner, trying to take the real world, stretch and hack it until it fits with the physical reality. I stress that the bill needs to be seen in that context. It is okay as far as it goes but it is a drop in the bucket compared with what needs to be done, particularly in restructuring the framework of economics.

Neither the government nor the opposition see the primacy of environmental considerations. To both of them, the environment is something you fit around those economic considerations, which are seen by them as being far more important. But the environment must come first and, as I said, we ignore it at our peril. The environment must be seen as the base upon which the economy rests. If we steadily erode the environment, if we steadily lose our biodiversity, if we steadily lose the ecology, which is what this bill is about, then there will be no economy at all.

The World Bank has come out with this rather remarkable statement that Australia is the richest country in the world. There has been a bit of discussion about this, most of which indicates that the context in which I am developing this argument today is not well understood on either side of this chamber. The World Bank is talking about real wealth, the natural wealth and the human wealth, on which the economic cash flow—the GDP or GNP—is based by extracting wealth from that natural capital account.

As I indicated earlier, there have been several studies which have attempted to modify these economic indices. They indicate that in the case of America and the United Kingdom there has been a decline in this modified gross domestic product since the mid-1970s. That indicates yet again that even on its own terms the economic system to which so much obeisance and credibility is given is not delivering even the material goods to the human population.

Given that sort of background, given the attitude of the government, and given the attitude of the opposition—which, as we heard from Senator Kemp, pretends to be the next government—we can hold very little confidence in the survival of the natural environment with its biodiversity and rich life supporting structures. I believe these supporting structures will continue to be eroded, either under this government or under the opposition if it should form a government, and that this government will achieve no more than a slowing down in the rate of its deterioration.

We could cynically remark that the success of these measures might be counterproductive because one of the peculiar things we notice about human beings is what is known as the boiling frog syndrome: if changes occur sufficiently slowly, people seem to be able to adapt to them. As we all know, a frog put into cold water which is slowly heated up will simply sit there and die, whereas a frog dropped into hot water will jump out very quickly. I expect that human populations are a bit like that. The legislation which is moved to slow down these changes and deterioration is likely to cause people to adapt and not react as severely as if environmental damage were occurring more quickly. So even bills like this may be counterproductive.

A cursory glance through schedule 1 of the principal act shows the scale of the problem with which we are dealing. Many hundreds of species are listed. Some, such as the thylacine and the lesser bilby, are already extinct, yet we continue to regulate their import and export. We are already a long way down the road to quite massive extinctions. In my own state of South Australia we have the worst record of mammal extinction anywhere in the world. This is not being prevented or slowed by this legislation or any other serious attempt.

Another two problems associated with this legislation are matters which I have drawn particular attention to many times in the past. Both relate to the development of this bill in accord with intergovernmental agreement—which Senator Kemp has already mentioned. He has mentioned it in rather praising terms; I would mention it in rather pejorative terms. The protection of the Australian environment and its biodiversity is indeed a national issue; it requires a national approach. When you involve intergovernmental agreements and those sorts of mechanisms, you necessarily involve a piecemeal approach and often finish up with the lowest common denominator.

The states are not all equally interested in and concerned about the environment, and the seeking of consensus is not the best way to arrive at national policy on the protection of species and their ecologies. I believe that we should be pursuing a national agenda and that we should be doing it through this parliament, not through those intergovernmental agreements. I would agree with Senator Kemp: discussion, with the feeding in of information, is an appropriate action to take. But ultimately, the responsibility for the protection of Australia's environment rests with this national parliament; it does not rest with the states.

Often in the past discussion that has gone on before a bill is prepared and presented to the parliament means that parliament is merely asked to rubber stamp what has already been agreed to—and this bypasses the democratic process. I think the opposition is in agreement with this. The issue comes up again in relation to international agreements in which the national government might have agreed internationally with other governments. When we are asked to pass legislation here and one attempts to move amendments to those international agreements, one is told, `No, you can't do that because we have agreed with 25 other countries that this is the format.' In that way the proper democratic process is bypassed. Again, for those reasons, I think one needs to be rather suspicious of this process of intergovernmental agreement as a way of achieving a national protective medium for protection of the Australian environment and its biodiversity.

In this particular case, I understand that the minister is prepared to entertain some amendments; therefore, what I have just outlined is clearly not the case. However, I just make that as a general proposition in relation to the many pieces of legislation of this type.

It is clear that in the past we have made enormous mistakes regarding the importation of exotic species into Australia. Many people have remarked on it. In fact, an expression that you hear almost every day is: Australia would have been a marvellous country if it had not imported so many pests. Wherever you look, you see pests of all sorts; every genus would have pest species that have been imported. Some of these may well have been genuine accidents. I suppose nobody wanted to import the Portuguese millipede which is, and for a number of years has been, infesting the Adelaide Hills quite severely. But many of these species have been deliberately brought in, with the very best of intention and with access to the very best information available at the time of import.

How good and how comprehensive is the information available to us today? I venture to suggest that, while it is better than it was when the rabbit was introduced, it is still not perfect; in fact, it is a long way from being perfect. The report on the pilchard deaths—and I notice that Senator Collins is in the chamber—illustrates it is not possible to rule out the possibility that the disease which was responsible for that massive fish kill was or was not caused by an introduced virus or protozoan. Not wanting to argue whether it was or was not, the fact that we do not know and cannot be certain indicates the lack of underlying knowledge which we need to sensibly control the import and export of species.

The Quantum program just last week dealt with the quite serious and massive deaths of frogs in the Queensland rainforests and suggested that this may, again, have been due to the importation of water along with exotic aquarium fish. Again, I am not arguing whether or not that is or was the cause; that is irrelevant. But it seems that, again, we cannot be certain whether or not that is true because of the paucity of information to properly regulate the movement of animals and plants from one part of the world to another. The precautionary principle should lead us to not doing something, if there is a chance that the results of doing that thing could be irreversible.

The minister's second reading speech indicates that the government is concerned at the possibility of the establishment of self-sustaining populations of exotic birds in the Australian wild. Surely the same concern should be expressed over self-sustaining populations of any exotic species, whether with species coming into Australia from outside or with Australian species being sent elsewhere. I throw that in because there has been a great deal of discussion recently, particularly on the part of the opposition, about getting an economic advantage from exporting Australian species to other countries. If we have poor knowledge about the effects of species coming into this country, one can imagine how little knowledge there may be in many other countries about the exporting of Australian species elsewhere.

The Democrats have amendments to this legislation, some of which I understand the government is prepared to accept. We support the bill but believe that much more needs to be done before our wildlife is managed on a long-term sustainable basis. The faults in this bill are not so much to be found in what the bill does not address but rather in the attitude of the government which gives such low priority to the protection of the Australian environment together with the multitude ecologies which it contains. In short, lip service only is being paid to the notion of sustainability but little is being done—and nothing, if it impacts on the principal economic objectives of the government.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1995, following the remarks made by Senator Coulter. I must say that he spoke in a very wide ranging way about many issues—although I do not know how much of his speech was actually addressed to the bill that is before us here this afternoon.

PARA.TAB: The legal and illegal export of Australian native animals has been the target of a great deal of speculation and rumour, fact and fiction, in recent years. When I was involved in the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare the issue of bird smuggling was raised several times and, while anecdotal evidence was abundant, there was little that the authorities seemed able to do to stem the trade. The amendments that this bill will put in place will improve regulatory controls on the import and export of animals and birds, with a view to ensuring long-term conservation of our native wildlife.

I think Senator Coulter—in saying basically that he is the font of all knowledge as far as environmental matters are concerned—does himself a fair bit of injustice. I know that on this side of the chamber we have a great deal of interest in environmental issues and have had for as long as I have been in the parliament, which has been for something like the last 10 or 11 years.

The bill, in essence, says that commercial harvests of native Australian and certain overseas wildlife must be conducted on a sustainable basis, with no detriment to the long-term survival of any species. It also ensures that commercial exports can only take place when there is appropriate state and territory legislation in place and, to that end, it is the responsibility of the states and the territories to ensure sustainability of commercialisation. The bill also strengthens the enforcement powers of inspectors appointed under the act—and that can only be welcomed. The illegal trafficking of Australian wildlife is inhumane and we need to be mindful of the range of rare and endangered species that have the potential to be wiped out by mindless, greedy acts of illegal smuggling. The national registration system for certain species of exotic birds is also significant.

The bill also limits the number of native household pet animals that can be exported. I am not sure whether my office was the one to have been targeted to receive more mail on this bill than any other office, but suffice it to say I have received many letters from various elements within the agricultural industry—an industry which I understand attracts some 1.5 million people to it. The number of people who keep animals never ceases to amaze me. As patron of the RSPCA in New South Wales, I must say that just about every household seems to have a pet of some shape, shadow or form.

The Australian Avicultural Protection Association is quite opposed to the legislation, claiming that the industry has been denied access to information about the amendments. They argue that the legislation is an intrusion into their hobbies and their businesses and that it will have the opposite effect in that the smuggling of birds will return to the pre-1989 levels, which I understand were higher than that which is currently believed to exist. I have similar letters from people who describe themselves as private bird keepers and who see this legislation as unnecessary bureaucratic intervention in their lives.

Other groups, such as the Associated Bird Keepers and Traders, offer support for the legislation, suggesting that vested interest groups have an interest in delaying the process. They argue that all aviculturalists have had the opportunity to voice their opinions and to have delegates attend meetings. I understand that one of the reasons for the delaying tactics in New South Wales is to ensure that the New South Wales legislation precedes the federal legislation so that some birds can be declared legal.

As Senator Kemp said, this legislation is a step in the right direction. He also said that it is an issue that is very complex. But I am concerned we have a piece of legislation that has not had the full exposure to industry that it might have had. I recall a similar diversity of views some years ago among deer breeders, some of whom supported legislation affecting their industry and others who opposed it. The legislation was taken through the Senate rural and regional affairs committee and, at the end of the day, it was simply a case of the affected parties being given an opportunity to air their views and to work through a compromise.

My concern with this legislation is that it will not have the desired outcomes it is designed to have and that it will become merely another revenue process for government. As I have said before, I have no hard evidence of the smuggling of wildlife in or out of Australia; but, like so many other Australians, I am appalled at the efforts people go to in smuggling wildlife and the usually fatal results it has for the wildlife involved. I remain concerned about what other goods may be involved in the import and export trade. Having said that, I think the committee stage of this bill will actually weed out some of the concerns and some of the worries some people may have and hopefully come up with the right result in the final analysis.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are considering a bill to amend the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982. This is an act which attempts to enshrine the findings of the 1973 report of the Australian House of Representatives select committee on wildlife conservation, itself a response to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, or CITES, and the IUCN red data book of the world's endangered species. As such, it seeks to protect Australian and foreign endangered native animals and plants, including those threatened with extinction, by regulating their import and export. In this intention, the act is widely regarded as effective and necessary.

PARA.TAB: This process of its amendment provides us with an opportunity of fixing up the loopholes that currently exist to make it do justice to the enormous amount of natural wonder that Australia possesses in the form of its bio-diversity and native species. With the aim of improving the act, there are some problems that the Greens see associated with the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill. I would be grateful if the minister cleared up some of these ambiguous or grey areas or aspects that currently exist about the intentions of his act over these areas.

It is of great concern to us that in the amendment to this act the Commonwealth is apparently seeking to allow an import of the skins of panthera pardus, a spotted cat that is listed as vulnerable with CITES. It is commonly known as the leopard and it is allowed into Australia under quota. Where the main reason for the importation of the skins into Australia would be as a result of hunting expeditions into Africa by Australians, this amendment seems to be blatantly condoning a gratuitous and unnecessary practice which is helping to push species such as the leopard into the endangered zone and eventually into extinction. As responsible members of the international community with such ecological wealth as we possess in Australia, we cannot condone actions that would strip other countries of theirs.

Some of the components of the definition of plant and animal specimens in both the current act and the amendments do not include certain important types of animal or plant products. A concern of the Worldwide Fund for Nature was the lack of controls on the export of dead marine fish from Australia. Species such as the eastern gemfish, orange roughy or deep sea perch and southern bluefin tuna are under threat from such lack of controls. The act needs to be amended to deal with this inadequacy.

Secondly, as the act stands at present, few controls exist over the import and export of seeds. Thirdly, although agricultural weeds are covered by the Commonwealth Quarantine Act, there is no provision in respect of the contamination of the Australian environment by environmental weeds from other countries. This has been a significant problem in the forests and woodlands of Australia due to lax legislative control and it is an issue that needs to be remedied.

With regard to the proposed Democrat amendments dealing with a prohibition on the sale of endangered species imported in contravention of the act and of species otherwise illegally imported under the act, this is another important change to the act that is necessary to ensure that its stated aims are fulfilled. However, this amendment needs to take into account the relevant affected communities—for example, the Chinese medical community, which draws many of its medical resources from animals native to foreign countries.

As the import of these medical resources may become illegal under the act, a comprehensive and culturally sensitive program of public education and awareness must be commenced by the government in conjunction with state governments, health authorities and the communities involved. To facilitate this, the Greens will be suggesting an extension of the time given before the commencement of this section of the act—namely, 12 months—and we have proposed an amendment to that effect.

Finally, if Australia is to move into the 21st century having reduced its appalling record for species extinction, the increased legislative controls that this bill and its amendments propose for the wildlife protection act must be accepted. But there is much more we must do. Biodiversity is one of the most precious environmental assets in the world. It is the cup from which future generations will drink and the essence of the process of evolution on which the ecosystems of this infinitely complex globe are based. We are only part of this web of evolution and we must do all in our power to make sure it continues.

TALK.START.PARA: —When we last dealt with this matter we were talking about whether or not it is possible to create monopoly conditions through shape trade marks. There were concerns about not knowing what the courts would find in such instances. I have noticed quite a few advertisements on billboards which show just the shape of a cool drink bottle. There seems to be some expectation by industry that this will come about.

PARA.TAB: The same issue applies to other sensory signs—sound, colour and smell. Already, we see industries like the perfume industry, the wine industry and so on lining up to try to register the smell of their products as trade marks. People who make the decisions on registration say they would not do so and explain why. I believe them, but I know that once sensory trade marks are allowed in law, companies will try it on again and again.I am less sure about the integrity and understanding of courts. I think if guidelines are created, companies which seek to register smell as trade marks will work out ways to meet the guidelines which will satisfy the courts, if not the people who register the trade marks.

There is another implication here. Although the regulators might have always found against such improper use of sensory labels and shape and might express their intention to continue to do so, we must remember that this legislation includes another change—the reversal of the onus of proof. We have seen it on a number of occasions in recent times. After the passage of this bill the Trade Marks Registry will not have to prove why an application should not be accepted. While this might be reasonable with regard to labels, are they really ready to meet all the claims in relation to sensory signs? Yet this is exactly what they will have to do when this raft of claims on sound, scent, shape and so on comes through.

For this reason, I am proposing a simple amendment which will effectively delete reference to shape, smell, sound and colour, except as part of labels, an aspect of packaging, from the definition of `sign'. This is all that is required to eliminate reference to such things. If a case for registering any of these things is overwhelming, it can still be done. I understand that it has been done for pink batts and a very few other goods. Our amendment would not deprive manufacturers of the ability to identify their products in a way that would allow consumers to differentiate. That is the purpose of trade marks. Our amendment might compromise the marketing plans of big transnationals or interfere with those who wish to break new ground in legal challenges. Somehow, that does not bother me. I commend our amendment to the Senate.

This amendment, as I mentioned, has the purpose of clarifying that we will not have a situation where a shape or, perhaps in the future, a smell, may be legally defined as a sign. TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes the amendment moved by Senator Margetts. The committee will appreciate that what we are doing here is very much in line with consultations we have had in the lead-up to this bill. As has been indicated already, the new definition of what may constitute a trade mark contained in the bill allows the registration of sounds, smells and the three-dimensional shape of goods as trade marks.

PARA.TAB: The position taken by the government is that in response to the developing marketing needs of business and in line with international developments in trade mark law, we have recognised that a wider range of matter, including aural and olfactory signs and the three-dimensional shape of an article, is being, or could in the future be, used to identify goods and services. The definition of what may constitute a trade mark has therefore been expressly widened to include sounds, smells and shapes.

While this definition makes it possible for such signs to be registered as trade marks, it does not guarantee that such registration will occur. The fact that it does not guarantee it gives some safeguard as to the sorts of concerns raised by the Greens and the Democrats. All trade marks, for instance, for which registration is sought must meet the criteria for registrability set out in the bill. These include that the trade mark must be able to be graphically represented and the trade mark must be capable of distinguishing the applicant's goods and services from those of other traders. So to be capable of distinguishing the applicant's goods or services, the trade mark must be something which is not an essential feature of the goods or services and is not something that other traders will use in the ordinary description of their goods or services.

I think there are safeguards in place to protect against excesses. The structure of the bill is such that to be eligible one must meet certain prerequisites. As a consequence, we think the definition proposed by the Greens is one that is too limiting in terms of the future prospects for development of industry and is out of line with contemporary and developing international trade mark practice and protection.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the international community is moving in a certain direction—there are thought to be considerable concerns within Australia about the direction that the community is moving in—does that mean that Australia must follow in that direction?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)
