SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will be opposing the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1995. This bill seeks to change the eligibility for child-care assistance for occasional care in long day care services to 12 hours per week. The coalition has a number of concerns with this bill and is unreservedly opposed to it.

PARA.TAB: The government have made a host of excuses for this legislation and they have thought of a number of reasons that they claim justify the 12-hour limit. In reality, however, it is nothing more than a way of saving the government money. It is a form of fiscal tightening which is masquerading under a professed desire to regulate the way in which child care is planned. It is a shame that those people who most need this fee relief, those in lower income groups, will be penalised by this government's attempt at what they would call economic management.

Approximately 40,000 families in which one or both parents are outside the labour force utilise child-care services. Child-care assistance is a scheme designed to help low and middle income earners. Non-work related care, the type of care that is most affected by this legislation, is greatly valued in the community by parents who believe that contact with other children enables their child to experience a range of social and developmental opportunities.

The first excuse the government raises in defence of this legislation relates to the 12-hour limit itself. Why was this arbitrary time frame chosen? The government claims that this represents the median time taken for child care each week. It says that 12 hours is equivalent to the time children spend in preschool each week. In reality, this restriction is not based on any strategy or philosophy about the future development of child care in Australia and it has placed further uncertainty on families who are continually forced to endure the broken promises of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). The government claims that there is a shortage of child-care places for working parents. The minister says that by restricting the amount of child care available for non-working parents this undersupply will be adjusted.

In June 1994, the Auditor-General stated in the report entitled Mind the children that access to non-work related care is not equitable as it depends on the availability of places rather than on the demand for care. There are approximately 90,000 below school age children who require child care for work related reasons and who are not receiving it. With unmet demand of this magnitude, those who are already at the bottom the child-care priority list should not be subjected to further discrimination. Why should lower income families be penalised for the ineffectual planning of child care by the government?

Both the Auditor-General's report and the Law Reform Commission report entitled Child care for kids examined the issue of affordability of care. Both found there were inequities in funding through child-care assistance and that, due to the occurrence of gap fees, the child-care assistance program had not succeeded in its goal of ensuring that a family's child-care costs are directly related to its ability to pay for care.

The Auditor-General found that the child-care assistance subsidy was `generous for wage and salary earners but gap fees restrict affordability for low and middle income earners'. This gives the lie to the government's pre-1993 election claim that occasional child care was an essential service for mothers, and, indeed, fathers, and that child-care payments should not be considered a welfare payment.

Mr Keating said, in February 1993, that `after years of lobbying by women, the Labor Party has decided to recognise child care as a basic right'. He described it as an Australian right, alongside education and health. In September 1995, we see that, in the scramble to make up for Mr Keating's extravagance on other matters, so-called rights are obviously only rights as long as it took to finish the last election campaign.

The coalition is also extremely concerned that the disallowable instruments and the guidelines have not been presented, at least to the coalition parties. I understand that other parties were presented with draft copies of these and it would have been courteous of the government, I suggest, to have circulated those guidelines amongst all the parties.

The amendments provide for an independent administrative mechanism to assess families' work related status for the purpose of gaining priority of access to a Commonwealth funded long day child-care service. Amendments to the Child Care Act 1972 in this bill allow a family's entitlement to child-care assistance to be assessed not only on the basis of economic need but also on the basis of the work related status of the family or other special circumstances.

It is a matter of concern that people must be registered with the CES before being considered to be looking for work. The range of work available and the ways in which jobs are obtained result in people not using the CES, or in people considering it to be not particularly helpful. Indeed, in another inquiry with which I have been involved—it is being conducted by the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training—the CES has been found to provide something like three per cent of those job vacancies which employers advertise. There are many other avenues which people use today in their efforts to find work. The requirement for registration with the CES in order to be considered for work related care will often be an unfair imposition to place on parents.

Ministerial guidelines will determine the special circumstances to be covered which may include children at risk of abuse or neglect, emergency situations, and families with a parent who, for medical or other exceptional reasons, is unable to meet the specified work related criteria.

Evidence given at the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs inquiry into this legislation suggested that many parents and carers were reluctant to advise of the problems they might have with the children and that, in any event, it was more effective for a service to identify problems in advance of serious abuse occurring. As the coalition members stated in their dissenting report, we believe this suggests that the department is not fully aware of the needs of different sectors of the community and the difficulty many parents and care givers may experience in identifying and solving problems when they do not have access to some respite care or to the assistance provided by a service such as family day care.

The detail of these special circumstances and the intention of the ministerial discretion with relation to these has not been announced. There is no justification for the extension of the minister's powers in this way. The provision of the bill dealing with disclosure and verification of family composition and work related status imposes yet another layer of bureaucracy on the provision of child care.

As I said, the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs held an inquiry into the legislation in the last sitting period. It was completely unacceptable that we had to report on legislation without being fully apprised of the detail with regard to the enabling legislation.

The passage of this bill has been notable for its complete lack of transparency and openness. It was announced as a budget measure without consultation with parents or the industry. In fact, every industry group that made representation to the Senate committee advised that it had no inkling prior to budget night of the fact that this was to be brought in as a budget measure. Parliament has been kept completely in the dark about the detail of the disallowable instruments.

One wonders why the government is so keen to avoid any discussion of this bill. I point out that to many people it represents total hypocrisy on the part of the government. They have spoken about child care as a right and about their commitment to parents and care givers in Australia and their ability to access affordable child care for their children. Suddenly, without any prior announcement, one door is totally slammed in the face of parents and care givers. It is for that moral reason alone that the government should be held to account on this legislation.

Of course, being kept in the dark could have something to do with the overwhelming objections to this legislation by the community. I have personally presented over 15,000 signatures in petitions demanding that this bill be dropped. The unanimous opposition to this proposed legislation has been quite remarkable. In the Senate inquiry, the minister herself admitted that her office received approximately 4,000 letters on the subject. She was unable to say how many were in favour of the legislation. I suspect that the five letters she read out for the benefit of the community affairs committee were the only letters in favour of it. She was forced to acknowledge that the vast majority of the letters were not supportive of the proposal.

Those in the community have very good reason to be opposed to the provisions in this bill. In the past the government has said that access to child care is a right and that families on lower incomes are entitled to child-care assistance to help them exercise that right. This government is now proposing to take that right away from families where one parent is not in paid employment.

Lower income families who are not able to purchase additional child-care hours at full cost will be most hard hit by this decision. The gap between rich and poor will be widened. This is only one of many ways in which this gap has been widened in the last 12 months alone by this uncaring government.

What is most galling in this budget decision is the government's absolute hypocrisy. The same budget which several months ago announced changes to the payment of child care also produced the agenda for families. The agenda for families document proclaimed:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government's priority has always been to those families most in need.
It goes on:

. . . our assistance to families must be equitable, so that families benefit according to need and so that extra support is available for families with special needs . . . based in consultations with families and an understanding of their needs and choices.

Every action by the government in relation to this legislation has been in total contradiction of the policy announced in the agenda for families and they should be brought to book on that account. How is it possible that the same government which produced this rhetoric could be so hypocritical as to introduce a bill that is inequitable and that discriminates against low income families who are most in need, where one parent is not in the work force? The government had no previous consultation with families or carers and only addressed the issues raised by concerned groups once the coalition initiated an inquiry into the proposed legislation.

PARA.TAB: These decisions will place great pressure on child-care centres where demand for work related care is already being met, particularly in Queensland and New South Wales where the expansion of the private sector has been most rapid. The Australian Federation of Child Care Associations has stated that the decision will cost thousands of jobs in child-care centres, will force many centres to close and will disadvantage tens of thousands of families.

Even today I had a letter from a child-care centre owner in Queensland whose demand for work related care is being met, and a large proportion of her clients are those people who need occasional care. She is now to say to them, `You can only have fee relief for 12 hours.' The restriction is totally commercially unrealistic: many centres will find it impractical to utilise the additional hours in the day as care is not generally provided on a sessional basis in private child care. It is not usual to book in for two or three hours. Centres now book half a day or a whole day and you cannot sell gaps, such as between 9 a.m. and 11 a.m. or between 3 p.m. and 5 p.m. That is a totally unrealistic appreciation of the way in which child-care centres work.

Many thousands of families will be adversely affected by this decision and families who were previously utilising non-work related care will find it financially impossible to continue to do so. They will pull out of places, which in turn means that centres will be forced to increase the fees across the board in order to maintain their financial viability. The Queensland Professional Child Care Centres Association has calculated that the change could result in an average increase in child-care fees of $18 a week.

The recent announcement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of the investigation by EPAC into child-care provision in Australia reflects his obvious lack of confidence in Senator Crowley, the Minister for Family Services. Last week I visited Tasmania, where the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training is having an inquiry into early childhood education in Australia. One of the Tasmanian government spokespeople said that we are now having something like three or four inquiries into child care. How does the industry feel with continual inquiries and continual re-assessment of the position being done by government? Centres cannot operate with a degree of commercial confidence and this recent piece of legislation that we are considering today in the Senate simply reinforces that insecurity and total change of the landscape every couple of months.

The need for an investigation is evident. This government's child care program is failing to meet the needs of parents and child-care providers—a fact the coalition has been aware of for some time. The bill reflects the government's failure to understand what child care provision is all about. It reflects the government's failure to be concerned about the needs of low income earners and their children and is yet another example of the government's child care disaster.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill, which is before us this evening, is really quite a simple piece of legislation. It is simple because it is enabling in nature. It merely sets a framework; the details are actually to be found in the ministerial guidelines.

PARA.TAB: Child-care assistance was formerly known as fee relief. It is a means tested payment assessed through the Department of Social Security, targeted to low and middle income families to make child care more affordable. The payment is made directly to child-care services, which must reduce the fees payable by parents accordingly. Currently the average weekly fee for 50 hours of care is about $140. That is about $28 a day. Child-care assistance has a ceiling of $112.50 for that 50 hours of care, or a rate of about $2.25 an hour. Parents effectively pay an income related fee up to that $112.50. Part of the gap between that amount and the weekly fee may then be recouped by working parents through the child-care cash rebate.

As I said, this bill itself is quite simple. However, in saying that, I wish to point out that it disguises the devil, which is found in the detail. It is the child-care guidelines that actually set the limit on eligibility for assistance for care which is deemed to be non-work related. That assistance, the government is now telling us, should be limited to 12 hours a week. I will go into that at length in a moment.

Before I do so, I would like to stress that the Democrats' aim has always been to be constructive and consultative and not obstructive. We have been consistent supporters of the government in the area of child care. That includes support—I must say crucial support—for the quite controversial accreditation scheme which was introduced last year. That was in the face of considerable criticism at the time which now, I am very pleased to say, has almost totally disappeared.

That history of cooperation, I believe, does give us credibility when we say to the government, `You've got it wrong this time. This legislation is nowhere near in a form that we can let through this place.' We base that belief on our research, on our record of consultation with the industry, indeed on all that has been said so far in the various submissions to the community affairs committee. That objection is coming from right across the industry—from the community based sector as well as the private sector.

We have, all up, several thousand pieces of correspondence. It runs to boxes. It shows I believe, that the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) has totally underestimated the amount of concern that is being created out there in the community. It is our view, that we may eventually get to the point of saying that we do need to look at non-work related care versus work related care. But what seems to have been overlooked is that there already is a prioritisation—categories 1, 2, 3 and 4—and if that is being implemented properly, a lot of what the government tells us is happening simply does not ring true. The government cannot present a credible argument about children from non-work related families taking the places of those from work related families when those criteria guidelines, those access criteria, are already there.

The possibility of some limitation on non-related care is just one piece of the puzzle. We do not know as yet what shape that piece of the puzzle should take or where it should go in the overall jigsaw. We need to have some certainty about what the picture finally looks like. To do that, we must make sure we have an integrated series of services at federal, state and local level, taking into account the needs of families and of course the needs of children.

Indeed, I would argue now, having listened through the committee hearings, that we do not even have all the pieces. I was amazed to find that there was a piece that we did not even know existed. There has been some planning done in New South Wales that sets out where services are and where they are needed. It is years out of date.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's one state.

—But we did not even know it had been done for one state. We now believe that another piece of the puzzle is emerging in Queensland, where the department has acknowledged that there are some overservices. But where are all the other bits of the puzzle? Where is the bit of the puzzle from my state of South Australia saying where the needs are in South Australia, where there is oversupply and where services have not been provided? We cannot find that information.

PARA.TAB: I have attempted to survey most child-care services across the country. What is coming back is a very complicated maze—a mixture of overservicing and dire need not being met, particularly in the Melbourne area. It seems that even getting work related care is almost impossible in some inner areas of Melbourne. Surely, we need to find all the pieces of the puzzle before we try to make the decisions we are trying to make now.

What developments are currently under way? Firstly, COAG is discussing this now. It has been looking at the matter of roles and responsibilities in the sector since February 1994—for 19 months—and is due to release a discussion paper in the next couple of weeks. So why are we dealing with this legislation today?

Secondly, the Australian Early Childhood Association is about to release a planning model for children's services. This has attracted the interest of all service provider organisations—from the community based child-care sector, to preschools and groups from the private side of the industry. In fact, so interested are these groups that they have given us a unanimous commitment to cooperate in developing this model to a stage where it can be adopted by government. If government will not go ahead and continue the facilitation of that process and show some interest, the Democrats are happy to step in and continue the process.

Thirdly, a couple of weeks ago, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) announced the establishment of a task force on the future of child-care provision in Australia by EPAC. We believe the establishment of that task force, along with the two other processes I have just mentioned, confirms that the government acknowledges it has to do more work in this area. It understands that there are gaps and bits of the puzzle missing. So I ask again: why are we going to proceed with this now?

Our recommendation is that we complete the second reading of the bill today but then delay the process until at least late November to allow further consultations and discussions. That is still our position after further negotiations and contact with the industry. I must stress that we prefer that position to the prospect of actually defeating the bill because, if we simply vote against the second reading, we will send the message to government that it can safely put this back in the too-hard basket and leave it until the election when it makes some sort of family policy announcement. Other than that policy, the government would think it does not need to make any substantial changes.

But changes are needed. The community sectors are asking for changes, because they are seeing the private sector setting up on their doorstep in an area where it is not needed. The private sector also, particularly in Queensland and New South Wales, is asking for changes, because it has established viable services only to see another centre allowed to operate across the road.

Local government is asking for changes, because at the moment they do not believe they have the planning powers necessary to say, `No, you do not need to establish another child-care service'—in whatever place that may be—`We already have four more services on our books for that locality, so we are going to refuse you planning permission.' The chances are that what will happen is that the people wanting to operate another child-care service will simply go through an appeals process. The councils are often worried about getting themselves into a legal nightmare. We have to have planning in this industry.

One of the things that has been mentioned time and time again through the committee process is the potential for harm to children who have come to rely on these services. This is a genuine concern and it has come from many groups, including those dealing with children who have specific needs, such as the southern child-care support program in South Australia. Many of these concerns, I am sure, can be met through proper consultations on the development of guidelines, but that still, as yet, has not happened.

The child-care industry says what it needs is an integrated planning model. The Democrats certainly agree. The industry says it has made this clear to government over a number of years. It was again made clear at the committee hearing. Developing such a model is in line with the recommendations of the Auditor-General's report No. 42 titled Mind the children. The first finding and the first recommendation of that report were both about Commonwealth-state relations; in particular, the need for cooperative planning. That is what the COAG process is all about.

The audit report suggests limits may be part of this process but not a solution in isolation. It emphasises that `recommendations need to be implemented in a controlled manner over a reasonable adjustment period so as not to undermine the viability of the child care industry as it now stands.' As Senator Troeth has already explained, we are likely to see businesses driven to the wall through this legislation. Surely sending small businesses into bankruptcy is not a good planning mechanism.

The report also emphasises that options be provided for respite care so that only a minimal amount of this care is provided by formal, high cost, long day care services. It appears that that process has not, at least not yet, been undertaken in a planned or detailed manner. We are not saying we need rigid planning—I think this was one of the things bothering the department—but we do need some overall look at where the needs are, particularly for specific sorts of services such as for babies and whether that need is being met at the moment.
The position is also supported by a quote from the November 1994 issue of Choice magazine, which looked in depth at child care. Choice said:

SPEECH.PARA: When attempting to find the best child care arrangement, (parents) have to deal with a mixed bag of service providers in an industry that is at best fragmented and at worst an absolute mess . . . There are very few referral or placement agencies in Australia that can assist parents to find an appropriate service, and the small number of government information services are so poorly publicised that few parents know they exist.

Not a great recommendation for the government I would suggest. I would hope that as a result of this debate and the lead-up to it that we will at least enter a dialogue with the government on planning.

PARA.TAB: The other area we should tackle up front is the question of cost. At the committee hearing we were told that the majority of the savings from the government's proposal would come from a `slowing of the rate of growth' of the industry. We believe that slowing, particularly in parts of Queensland, northern New South Wales and I suspect some areas in Sydney from our survey, will occur under the approach the Democrats are recommending—that is, that we simply leave this legislation on the table and we send a very clear message to anyone planning a child care service that they need to do their homework. They need to check at local government level, at state government level and at the federal department level as well.

At local government level they cannot necessarily rely on the statistics already collected. It may be a process of surveying the community in which they plan to set up a child care service to ascertain needs at the grassroots level because the planning processes, even at state government level, are probably not going to give them an accurate look at what is there at the moment.

For those services that are already at risk—and I would put in that category any of those services significantly relying at the moment on category four children—what we are trying to do now is change the rules in the middle of the game. Child care operators have entered in good faith into an industry they believe can offer them a reasonable standard of living. Yet, if those who are accurately following the priority guidelines, acting correctly, doing everything they know they should be doing have a significant number of category four children, the passage of this legislation will place them at risk.

It is quite clear that what is happening is an integration of children's services—that is, child care, kindergarten, preschool, et cetera. All of the planning for that is happening by default and not by specific design. State governments have to be actively involved in this process because I suspect some of them are deliberately hiding some of those bits of the puzzle in their pockets at the moment, trying to slip them quietly off into the federal government's pockets disguised as a tendering out process of children's services. A very clear message has to be sent to state governments that they have to be actively involved in this planning process and not in a process of simply cost shifting.

Still on cost, there are competing claims about the amount of savings available to the government from this 12-hour approach. We have seen Access Economic figures which indicate that the end result of a 12-hour limit in isolation could actually cost the government money, not save it in the longer term. Questions raised in works such as the Brotherhood of St Lawrence's Unequal lives and the Institute of Family Studies' Today's child care, tomorrow's children about the possible costs of not providing services for children from low income, non-working families have gone unanswered. I would be most interested in the minister's comments here today. I hope she will cover some of those issues as to who exactly are those children, what their needs are and what will happen to them if this arbitrary 12-hour limit is put in place.

In closing, I would like to make a couple of other points. One is about double dipping. We believe the practice of charging twice for a place—that is, if a booked person does not attend but is still charged and then there are overlapping children and the charge is still rendered—should be outlawed. This will probably involve a cap on child-care assistance available to centres, but we wish to discuss and negotiate with government on this issue.

Another point is to confirm our support for some measures the government is undertaking. One is the simplified application process, which will involve a slight downward adjustment of the income and assets test for child-care assistance. Another is a $2 increase in the minimum fee for child-care assistance and the rebate which is worth apparently about $83 million over four years. Another is an alteration to how changes in income will be dealt with, including entitlement for an immediate review if the family's income falls. I must stress here, Minister, that those changes could be introduced without any need for this legislation. They are separate. They can come in in regulations and be dealt with there.

What we will not support is an alignment downward of holiday fees for holiday periods to 50 per cent, which is the inadequate figure that exists at the moment for family day care services. We will also not support reductions in meal and transport allowances for family day care providers, especially in light of the Law Reform Commission's report and the Ramis report.

I finish where I started. The Democrats' aim is and has always been to be constructive, not obstructive. We have been consistent supporters of the government in the general area of child care. Our history of cooperation I believe gives us credibility when we have to say to government, `Hang on. You have not got it right this time.' We do not want the bill to be killed off because in our view the question of work status related limits for care and the whole issue of planning must be dealt with now and not shelved or put into the too hard basket. We also want real consultation and consideration to be given to planning and to involve the industry. As I said earlier, we have offered to facilitate that process for service providers from both the community based and private sectors of the industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak against the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill. As outlined by Senator Troeth, the coalition is opposed to this bill. I note in passing that I am disappointed to see that of the six speakers on this bill I am the only male. I share the view of the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) that males should participate in a lot of aspects relating to families, including shopping. I am sorry there are not more males participating in this very important debate on child care.

PARA.TAB: The bill before us proposes a limit of 12 hours a week on eligibility for child-care assistance for non-work related child care in long day care centres. The government claims this measure is designed to ensure that families who need child care to enable work force participation get priority places. That is the alleged purpose of this bill. But I suspect that what the government is concerned about is the very significant blow-out in expenditure of child care.

The budget papers do make the point that this measure is designed to save $152 million over the next four years. I would have thought that that figure looms large in the government's mind, particularly with the enormous problems it has with the blow-out in government expenditure generally and the deficit problem. I have to say that the government has very good cause to be worried about the blow-out in expenditure on child care.

If you look at the history of Commonwealth government expenditure in this area, it is quite remarkable. Apparently there was only $65 million spent on child care by the Commonwealth government as long ago as 1982-83. Expenditure in the current financial year is going to be $1,100 million, and it is forecast to rise to $1,500 million in 1998-99. That is an almost exponential growth in expenditure in this area. In fact, it has increased by 18 per cent per annum in real terms between 1983-84 and 1993-94, and it is still increasing at a somewhat similar rate. So we really have had a very massive increase in expenditure in this area.

The paradox is that part of that is, of course, a result of obviously increased demand for child care, and part of that increase in demand is a function of government economic policy. Increasingly, ordinary Australian families are saying to researchers that they need two incomes to maintain their standard of living, and to have two incomes they need child care. If you dispassionately look at the surveys of the attitudes of young working mothers, you find that very high proportions of them would prefer to be caring for their children, but they cannot afford to. They need child care and, therefore, we have this vicious circle, where the government is increasingly called upon to spend more and more money on child care. So it is appropriate that the government look at expenditure in this area and how to contain it.

As the Democrats have said and as my colleague Senator Troeth has said, this bill is not the way to go about addressing that problem. As Senator Lees says, there are clearly some doubts as to whether the $152 million savings forecast over the next four years will, in fact, be achieved. There must be real doubt about that, as there have been in other areas of government cost containment.

The major problem—certainly from my point of view—with this proposal is that it is simply further evidence of the government's active discrimination against single income families. That is what it really boils down to. We have complained long and loud about the government's discrimination, whether witting or unwitting, in terms of single income families.

I have made a particular point of complaining about the discrimination inherent in the operation of the child-care cash rebate and what is now called the parenting allowance. I do not need to repeat that, except to say that the rebate, as you know, has no income test whatsoever, while the parenting allowance has a very tight income test, although that has been relaxed a little. The rebate is still worth twice as much for a mother of two children in child care as the parenting allowance is worth for a mother of two. We have maintained that that is unacceptably unfair to mothers who sacrifice an income to care for their children. As a result of the government's policies in this area, there has been a nationwide protest movement against the policies of the government, against the discrimination, and I think it is going to cost the government dearly at the next federal election.

We have said before, and we will say it again, that we sympathise with the government's objective of wanting to save money. There is a very clear way in which they could do that, and that would be to place an income test on the rebate. We argued that case when the rebate bill was before us. Your own former finance minister, Senator Peter Walsh, has argued the case, and many social commentators have argued the case, for some sort of income test on the rebate. The rebate itself is an example of runaway expenditure. It cost the taxpayer $90 million in 1994-95 to subsidise child care in this way, and it is going to cost a forecast $137 million in 1998-99. That is a 50 per cent increase in expenditure in this area in the next four years. Of course, it costs $15 million a year on top of that to administer the program through the Health Insurance Commission.

This debate needs to be seen in the context of what we believe is the discrimination that the government has been practising in relation to the child-care cash rebate on single income families. It is our view that this proposal will widen that discrimination. It widens it by limiting access to long day care to 12 hours a week for `non-work related child care'. We have had submissions from the Australian Federation of Child Care Associations, and I think they need to be listened to. As they say, this proposal is particularly going to hurt single income, low income and one income families. That is the tragedy of this proposal and why we have great reservations about it.

We do believe that it, unfortunately, is typical of the adhockery of the government's approach to child care, and Senator Lees spoke eloquently on that subject. I think the core of the government's problem in this area is its mind-set. It seems to be stuck with that union based 19th century approach to what is work and what is not work, and it is designing all programs of assistance in this area around those arbitrary definitions of `work' and `non-work'.

This proposal is fundamentally based on that arbitrary division of labour, and it seems to us entirely inappropriate in the late 20th century. Whether it is true or not, it does appear that this policy is all about helping only two income families. That is what the effect of this is. If you are a two income family, you will not be affected by this. If you are a one income family, forget it, because you will be hurt by this proposal. It seems to us that the government is out of touch with the reality of the modern lives and aspirations of many families, and many women in those families, and that is why it is stuck in this ancient mind-set.

In many modern families, there is a lot of flexibility about the way their family arrangements are conducted and made. That is increasingly the case, and that particularly relates to young mothers in terms of their activities—whether they are doing paid work, unpaid work, study, volunteer work or whatever. I suppose, to take a personal example, my wife is the classic case. For the 10 years we have had young children, she has had a variety of activities, including casual paid work and volunteer work for my party, the preschool, the kindergarten, the school and other activities. So, in terms of what she does as a young woman in modern society, what is work and what is not work when you look at the enormous range of activities which she—and she is typical of all her friends—does? I think that is the fundamental problem with this bill.

The bill is going to depend, at the end of the day, on bureaucrats determining what is work related child care and what is non-work related child care. That is the only way in which this bill can operate, and I think that is the fundamental problem with it and why it is unacceptable. It is based on a quite arbitrary and out-of-date idea about what is work and what is not work. I just do not think government assistance for child care in particular should be based on those sorts of arbitrary distinctions between what is work related and what is not work related. Child-care assistance should be based on need, financial need, and that is why we have talked about income tests in the past. To try to get a whole bureaucratic empire built around trying to decide what is work and what is not is hopeless and doomed from the start.

The bill itself, in trying to go down this path, contradicts what the government itself says in the children's services program is the objective of child care. It says that it is to assist families with dependent children to participate in the work force and the general community. So it would seem to us that what is being proposed here completely contradicts that stated objective of the government's program. The program objective is not to distinguish between `work related' and `non-work related', yet that is the fundamental premise of the bill we have before us. I think this bill is a case of the government unwittingly meddling in the choices that families seek to make about how they structure their lives and about their work, whether it is volunteer work or paid work, and about how the children are looked after.

The minister did say today, in answer to Senator Troeth's question, that the government does not interfere in those choices. Here we have a bill on this very day which does exactly that, and that is why I took note of the minister's answer today. The fact is that the government does—albeit often unwittingly—interfere in the choices made by families in its tax and benefit policies. I think that is unfortunate and one of the real problems with this bill. Those sorts of choices should be left to families to make, and they should not be penalised or rewarded one way or the other.

The government does, in fact—whether it meant it or not—reward families where both parents are in the paid work force and the children are in child care. In a relative sense, it penalises families where the family makes a choice that one parent is going to stay out of the paid work force and care for the children, care for elderly relatives or do volunteer work in the community. They are going to be penalised. They are penalised through the tax system; they are penalised through the operation of the child-care cash rebate; and they are penalised through the operation of this particular bill.

There are a number of other grounds on which the bill is objectionable. They have been outlined by both Senator Lees and Senator Troeth. The Federation of Child Care Associations summarised them very well. They claim, and we have no basis on which to disagree, that the bill will cause the closure of some centres which are premised on there being a supply of children who are there for non-work related child-care reasons.

If that is the case, that will of course cause the loss of child-care workers' jobs. That could well have the consequence of increasing long day care fees and therefore the gap fee. As we and the federation have said, this will hurt non-working, single and low income families. I think Senator Lees put it very well. The problem is that this is changing the rules in the middle of the game. Those were Senator Lees's words. I think they are very proper.

Private child-care centres are badly affected by this bill for that reason. They have made their investments, their planning and everything else on the basis of the rules as they stood about access to child care and access through the child-care assistance scheme. Now the rules are being changed in a way which will obviously affect them badly. It will affect them financially and affect the provision of care, which is what we understand the government is all about. Unfortunately, through this proposal the government is simply adding to the complexity, the unfairness, the adhockery and what we believe is the ideological rigidity of government policy in this area. Therefore, we oppose this bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Omit all words after "That", substitute:
"1.for the reasons set out in paragraph (3), further consideration of the bill be postponed and be made an order of the day for Monday, 20 November 1995.
"2.Senators who have spoken to the motion "That this bill be now read a second time" may speak again to that motion for up to 20 minutes each when the bill is again called on.
"3.The reasons referred to in paragraph (1) are as follows:

Passage of the bill now would be precipitate and ill-advised in the absence of imminent or forthcoming information, recommendations and necessary consultations which bear directly on the likely purpose, impact and effectiveness of the bill, including in particular:

PARA.TAB: (a)publication, by the Australian Early Childhood Association and the National Children's Services Forum, of the planning model for the children's services industry; and
(b)publication and distribution of a discussion paper on a National Framework for Children's Services by the Council of Australian Governments, which is due in a matter of weeks; and

(c)possible shifts in the Government's position regarding an hourly or daily limit to be applied to eligibility for Child Care Assistance for non-work related child care—a limit that would be made possible by the passage of this bill".

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleagues have already very adequately outlined the purposes of the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill and the problems associated with it, and I will not cover that similar ground. One aspect I want to focus upon has already been described by Senator Minchin as an arbitrary and out-of-date distinction between work and non-work. That is the point that the Greens (WA) want to make in relation to this bill.

PARA.TAB: The bill makes a strong ideological statement regarding the position and value of `non-working' parents and the construction of gender roles. The government's problem with the fee structures of child-care centres and/or double-dipping from the child-care industry is a separate issue, an industrial issue, and could be dealt with perhaps within the accreditation scheme. At home parents and their children should not be penalised for the failures and inefficiencies of the child-care industry and/or state governments. The child-care industry must become more flexible to consumer needs. To this end, the New South Wales Community Child Care Association is interested in working with the federal government to restructure the industry to avoid these industrial problems.

This bill divides women by creating a two-tiered system: women who deserve child-care assistance and women who do not. Women at home are considered to be not working and to have freely chosen this option, and they must therefore accept the economic disadvantage—notwithstanding unemployment, lack of marketable skills and so on.

Dr Colette Taylor from the National Advisory Council on Child Care advises that quality child care is a positive contributory factor in child development, although this is not essential if there are compensatory environmental factors. Since child-care assistance is already means tested, who will be disadvantaged by the cutback? The most vulnerable women and children. Few women in this low income category have equal choices regarding work and non-work. Many are rural, unemployable, in temporary situations, de-skilled, living within ethnic traditions or have husbands in the process of relocating. Some may even choose to stay at home with their children.

This bill clearly disadvantages those so-called non-working parents. Staying at home with children full time puts enormous stress on family life. There are potentially negative health repercussions for women not having adequate access to respite. Family life is also affected as well as health.

This bill reinforces the idea that parents who are not in the work force are not working. It does nothing to address the consideration of women's unpaid work and the need for the inclusion of unpaid work in the national accounts. A comment by the Women's Electoral Lobby is very pertinent here. As well as wanting that kind of consideration in the national accounts, WEL made the comment that this bill also reinforces the government's agenda of constructing the role of women as workers. Women will progressively face the same discriminations that non-working men face, regardless of the socioeconomic environment, and be penalised for not working.

Not only are women penalised but so are their children. The government's argument that the long day care centres exploit the system by charging a full day for fewer hours used is not the fault of women and children. They should not be used to fix this problem. To reiterate, it is an industrial problem. Long day care centres should be more flexible and consumer oriented to meet the accreditation criteria. The government should use the accreditation process to bring private day care up to the mark.

Senator Lees referred to the attempt towards cost shifting being made by the states. In a similar fashion, if the states are not fulfilling their role in relation to preschools, the federal government must deal with that as a separate issue. Women cannot be the scapegoat for Treasury's problems. Child care should focus primarily on the needs of children. Child care is a very important educational and social vehicle for young children, and children need child care. This bill is interventionist it its approach. It is taking away the role of child-care centres in determining allocations of `priority four' places. It is not proper to penalise the access of those children by means of this legislative device.

The Australian Democrats have moved an amendment which will allow a delay in consideration of this bill. The Greens support the Democrat amendment, even though we can give no commitment to passing the bill at the proposed date of their motion if no changes occur. So it is basically up to the government. If the government or the opposition support the Democrat motion, there will be further opportunity for consultation and change. If not, because we do not support the bill in its present form, it will fail now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill and to make a couple of points. I would like to start with Senator Troeth's assumption or comment that there was no consultation with the industry prior to the budget. Either Senator Troeth is foreshadowing a new way that the opposition will bring down its budgets or she does not understand the process that budget measures do involve consultation beforehand. That is a very important point that I think needs to be raised.

PARA.TAB: Senator Troeth also spoke about a large number of letters. What she failed to say about those letters is that they were form letters from a collection of areas. It is important to realise that they came from selected areas. The majority were certainly from Queensland. There are obviously problems up there.

This bill will not change Western civilisation as we know it. It will guarantee the children of families that do not have both parents at work or, in the case of single parent families, one parent at work, access to 12 hours of care a week. That is about the average for preschool. We have heard a lot about that point—that this is about the average for preschools.

Those opposite keep talking about preschools, but what we have not heard very much about is that preschool is for the year or maybe the 18 months before children go to school; that is, it is for the time just prior to their reaching the age of about five. We have not heard from any of the people opposite anything about the fact that there is still a shortage of nought to three places within child care for work related child care. That is the critical age group that people seem to be forgetting.

We also have not heard about the hours these centres are opened or where they are positioned, like not positioning them anywhere near where major employment is so that people can drop their children off as they leave home. For example, on the Central Coast of New South Wales, people who work in Sydney are spending an hour to an hour and a half travelling each way each day. If the child-care centres are situated close to their homes but are open only from, say, 7.30 or 8 in the morning to 5.30 or 6 in the evening, no person working in the city has a snowflake's chance of utilising the child-care centres close to their home.

The child-care centres say, `We have a centre here and we cannot get people to fill it.' It is a bit like train timetables—there's never a train when you want the rotten thing. There are a number of situations that show that the placement and hours of opening of child-care centres are not appropriate to the needs of the people using them.

I have no hesitation in saying that child care for work-related needs has to be our prime consideration. There are a lot of single parents out there, as well as double income parents, who have this need. There is also a need for people to access education. People are allowed to do that under these circumstances but that just keeps being temporarily forgotten.

We have to be aware that access to child care is important but looking after children is more than putting them in child-care centres. We have to be aware that the needs of children and the needs of families to be supported in their caring role is not solved just by child-care services. It is solved by looking at a very wide range of things.

Parenting is one of the very few occupations in this or any other country for which you require no qualifications, no training, no degrees, no education, no support, nothing. You can rear a family on your own with nothing being offered. The opposition—we heard this from Senator Troeth—has said how important this sort of care is but what Senator Troeth is ignoring is what the states are doing.

She should look at what is happening in her state of Victoria with the early childhood services—the restriction on the number of times a family can take their babies and young toddlers to early childhood nurses, people who are in the business of caring and providing support and education to families. We hear from the opposition how wonderful child care is but the same opposition supports people who have cut other services to families with children—a slight double standard I think.

One very important service for families with children, particularly where there is one family member at home—as a former early childhood nurse, I speak with some experience—is the provision of occasional care. If 12 hours a week had been available in the years when I was practising, many families would have found that a wonderful boon, enabling them to meet their commitments outside, to do their shopping, to enable their children to socialise, to enable mum or dad, whoever the key carer is, to catch their breath and get on with living. But we also need parenting programs—the systematic training for effective parenting—those types of skills, those types of programs.

Child care is an integral part of supporting the family but it is not the only part. One witness pointed out how vitally important it was for low socio-economic families to access 60 hours of child care a week. Good parents come in all shapes and sizes and from all socio-economic categories. They have a number of things in common. They do not need to be told that they need to put little Johnnie or Susan at age two into child care for 60 hours a week because they can be better cared for in a child-care centre. That is not the way we should be supporting our families. I am all in favour of 12 hours a week but this is all about what people get when they access preschools.

Another interesting thing I noted was the names of a number of centres included the words `kindy' or `preschool'. That gives the immediate impression that this is not a long day child-care centre, it is a kindy with 9 to 3 sort of hours, which I thought was most misleading.

Senator Minchin said that a big proportion of mothers prefer to be at home caring for their children. I think that is right. I therefore assume that a big proportion of mothers do not want to be sending off their children to long day care centres for any more than about 12 hours a week because they are enjoying being with their children, being able to reinforce and work with programs that the centres are using, making sure that both sides benefit.

I also found it interesting that whereas the opposition is opposed to this legislation and also appears to be opposed to increased expenditure on child care we have not heard any policies from them, apart from income testing. I thought that was very interesting. Again, they are opposing things but offering no policy changes, no policy direction, no policy about where they think they might want to go. If the legislation is so bad, they should be looking at how it can be fixed, but that is not their way of operating.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just be patient.

—I am very patient; it will be a long, long time. Another interesting figure I have been given is that if a child starts in long day care at a fairly early age, by the time he or she starts school they could have spent up to 12,500 hours in child care. That is only about 500 hours less than they will spend at school in their 13 years of schooling. That is something to ponder.

PARA.TAB: Good quality and affordable child care has always been a priority of this government, as more and more women take up the opportunity to work, study and train. There are very liberal interpretations of the categories of working and non-working. As Senator Minchin was so concerned about it, he should carefully read what those categories mean because the interpretation is very liberal.

The other thing that came out very clearly in the hearings was that there was quite a deal of cost shifting attempted by some of the states, as we see the number of children in the 3 1/2 to four years age group using our scheme instead of the preschool system. The states should be condemned if they think they can slide out of their responsibilities for early childhood education in that way.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Mobile Phone Towers in School Grounds

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the Senate's attention to the siting of mobile phone towers, MPTs—also called cellsite masts—in school grounds. The implications for children's health are my primary concern. But other issues, such as privatisation and sponsorship are also important.

PARA.TAB: In Christchurch, New Zealand, this year, the Ministry of Education reversed a decision to allow Telecom to approach schools for permission to erect mobile phone transmitters on school grounds. This followed a stormy debate about the safety of MPTs, when Telecom New Zealand approached seven schools for permission to rent space for $4,500 per year. Parents felt that, lacking conclusive evidence that transmitters were not harmful, even the slightest risk of harming children's health was not worth taking. Their Ministry of Education agreed.

The New Zealand policy change was partly due to two recent studies. One of those studies was by Dr Neil Cherry of Lincoln University, Christchurch, in April 1995. His report, entitled Potential and actual adverse effects of cellsite microwave radiation, in summary states:

SPEECH.PARA: Microwave radiation is a contaminant.

The Precautionary Principle should be recognised due to the lack of full scientific certainty. In the case of cellsite (mobile phone site) microwave radiation it suggests the application of minimal exposure and prudent avoidance, especially for the very young, child-bearing women and the elderly.

PARA.TAB: Children absorb microwave radiation at a greater rate than adults—in fact, 3.3 times of radiated power per kilogram than an adult. There is a strong interaction of the mutagenic potential of microwave radiation which urgently needs to be re-evaluated.

Dr Cherry's report further recommends recognising the epidemiological and biophysical evidence which points to significant actual and potential adverse human health impacts due to cumulative effects of continuous, pulsed, low levels of microwaves, such as those radiated from cell sites, with such adverse effects as DNA breakdown, leukaemia, miscarriage and reduced immune performance. Tower sites should not be located in or near schools, kindergartens, daycare and play centres where children and pregnant mothers spend long periods of time. They should be separated from schools and residences by such distances that the intensity of the microwaves, when averaged over a year, does not exceed 0.1 microwatts per square centimetre.

The second report, from Australia's CSIRO Division of Radiophysics, of June 1994, called the Status of research on biological effects in safety of electromagnetic radiation: telecommunications frequencies, was initiated by the Spectrum Management Agency, SMA, to review worldwide research on effects of radiofrequency radiation on humans. Contrary to SMA's public position, it documents many adverse health effects of radiofrequency at power levels well below the threshold for thermal effects. It includes epidemiological studies showing increased risks of leukaemia, eye cataracts and a suspected link with breast cancer. The CSIRO study also found that there can be adverse effects on human immune systems below maximum permitted levels of 1 milliwatt per square centimetre.

In the United States, Motorola, the US telecommunications corporation, has a policy of not siting radio antennas on school property—due to growing public opposition to MPTs in or near school grounds. In San Francisco the proposal to put a low-power radio transmitter on the roof of a public high school prompted the city's school board to prohibit MPTs on school property. Their decision was based on advice from Dr Raymond Neutra of the California Department of Health Services who said, `Other than the rental income, why would a responsible public agency go out of its way to expose children to an agent that was not necessary for their education and was not thoroughly studied?'

In Sydney, the Harbord community has objected to Telstra's decision to erect a MPT next to the local kindergarten that has been operating for over 40 years. Parents were not convinced by assurances from the Australian Radiation Laboratory that emissions were well below the Australian safety standards and were removing their children from the place, so the kindergarten was facing closure. Eight days of protest and parents chaining themselves to the gate forced Telstra to reverse its decision—a significant victory.

It needs to be strongly stated that these parents took the only option open to them, that of protest action. The federal government's exemptions granted to the telecommunications industry provide it with immunity from all state and local planning and environment laws that apply to any other individual or business.

In Adelaide, 11 citizen groups are campaigning to have the South Australian Minister for Education ban MPTs on school grounds. Press reports reveal that the South Australian government is considering whether to permit mobile phone towers in schools and, if permitted, under what guidelines. One proposal is by Telstra-Vodaphone to site a MPT adjacent to a kindergarten in Mitcham. A Telecom radiation expert conceded during a visit to the site that `it was inadvisable to position these towers beside schools or kindergartens'. One must ask: why? Dr George Tallis, consultant endocrinologist and chemical pathologist from Flinders Medical Centre advised Mitcham Council in February 1995:

SPEECH.PARA: Current medical evidence is insufficient to decide whether electromagnetic radiation is carcinogenic or not. The standards are all quite arbitrary. In their submission Austel indicated that they are currently researching the issue. $1.2 million has been awarded to Royal Adelaide Hospital physicist, Dr Michael Repacholi, to look at relevant radiation effects in mice. The US have already committed $65M US to ongoing research. This is science in evolution.
Dr Tallis referred to a recent paper from Mount Sinai Medical Centre, New York, that stated:

. . . until recently the effects of low level radiation have been underestimated. Effects of weak electromagnetic fields on living systems are currently being intensively studied, and clear effects have been established. A number of experiments have demonstrated that weak electromagnetic fields are capable of eliciting effects in different biological systems.

So why do we have this conflict? Unfortunately, official policy considers only thermal biological effects in setting safety standards. These result from high levels of electromagnetic radiation which have sufficient energy to heat up body tissue. This school of thought is represented by Dr Michael Repacholi, chair of the recent Standards Australia subcommittee, which recommended increasing present levels by a factor of five. On page 41 of the proposed standard, it reads:

. . . when only the established . . . literature is used, exposure limits can only be based on thermal effects in the frequency range about 10Mhz to 300Ghz. The . . . literature shows that while non thermal exposures may cause very minor perturbations to biological systems (isolated cells or tissues, but not in humans) there has not been found any adverse health impact from these exposure levels after almost 40 years of research.

This approach denies the growing body of scientific research indicating that low level, non-thermal—athermal—levels of radiofrequency radiation may very well be hazardous. On 25 July my office wrote to Professor Ross Adey, the US veterans' administration senior researcher at its medical centre in California. Professor Adey is a world authority on the biological effects of radiofrequency and microwave radiation. He is currently conducting multimillion dollar research funded by Motorola, the world's biggest mobile phone company. Professor Adey was asked by my office, `Based on the current scientific knowledge, is it advisable to base radiofrequency maximum exposure limits—standards—solely on thermal effects?' Professor Adey replied:

You ask about exposure limits based on thermal effects. The laboratory evidence for athermal effects of both ELF and RF/microwave fields now constitutes a major body of scientific literature in peer-reviewed journals. It is my personal view that to continue to ignore this work in the course of standard setting is irresponsible to the point of being a public scandal. Please be advised that the US National Council of Radiation Protection and Measurements has recently established a committee with the sole mandate of reviewing the role of modulation effects with health implications, in conditions where athermal exposures are paramount. Committee 53 of NCRP published its report in 1986 and drew attention to the potential importance of ELF modulation patterns in determining health-related effects. Indeed, the very existence of modulation frequency-dependent effects bespeaks athermal interactions.

Is it advisable then to place MPTs on or near school grounds, playgrounds and so on using safety standards which ignore a large body of scientific evidence which indicates a potential health hazard to children? If it is not advisable, why allow it? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 13 April 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the Government plan to extend the cross runway at Brisbane Airport; if so, when is this planned to be completed.
(2) What would be the cost of extending the cross runway at Brisbane Airport.
(3) Would an extension of the cross runway at Brisbane Airport result in a reduction or an increase in the number of people affected by aircraft noise and in the frequency and severity of such noise.
(4) What percentage of aircraft taking off and landing at Brisbane Airport fly over residential areas.
(5) Does the Minister currently have the power to impose a curfew at Brisbane Airport.
(6) What is the current situation regarding any curfew at Brisbane Airport.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Government does not plan to extend the cross runway at Brisbane Airport.

(2) The FAC advises that the cost of extending the runway to a length of 2600 metres, and adequately to support operations of an Airbus A300, would be around $150m. The June 1991 Task Force Report commissioned by the Department of Transport and Communications estimated the cost of extending the runway to a length of 3600m, suitable for unrestricted operations of B747 aircraft, to be approximately an additional $228 million.

(3) This question can be answered with reference to the noise impacts of different runway options at Brisbane Airport as considered in the June 1991 report of the Task Force to Review the Operation and Planning of Brisbane Airport to Minimise the Impact of Aircraft Noise on Surrounding Communities. Using a methodology based on a study carried out by the National Acoustic Laboratories, the analysis of the options showed that:

Using the current north-south runway as the main runway in 2010, approximately 1,900 people would be at least moderately affected by aircraft noise, including around 400 people who would be seriously affected.

If the cross runway were extended to 2600m and used as the main runway in 2010, approximately 300 people would be at least moderately affected by aircraft noise, including around 100 people who would be seriously affected.

If the cross runway were extended to 2600m and traffic were distributed between the two runways based on the projected 1995 traffic mix, approximately 1300 people would be at least moderately affected by aircraft noise, including around 300 people who would be seriously affected.

It should be noted that with the transfer of operations to an extended cross runway, there would be a number of people living close to the extended centreline of the cross runway that would be newly affected by aircraft noise.
(4) Airservices Australia advises that approximately 50 per cent of aircraft taking off, and 36 per cent of aircraft landing, fly over residential areas.
(5) Yes

(6) There is currently no curfew applying at Brisbane Airport. The original Master Plan for the new Brisbane International Airport was predicated on the airport being curfew free. The Master Plan cited a combination of more stringent aircraft noise standards, the phasing out of older, noisy aircraft and greatly increased separation of residential areas from runways as reasons why a curfew should not be introduced for the new Brisbane Airport.

The Government established a Task Force in 1989 to make recommendations on how the impact of aircraft noise arising from operations at Brisbane Airport could be minimised, while still providing an airport that would meet Brisbane's needs into the future. In accordance with the original planning criteria for the airport, one of the guidelines that the Task Force was required by the Government to take into account was that Brisbane Airport was to remain curfew free.

(4) Does the Minister agree that the following scenario is at odds with the objectives of the Defence White Paper referred to in question 3: a civilian employee with the department is asked to undertake a period of full-time service with an Australian Defence Force (ADF) reserve unit, an application for leave without pay is approved on the basis that the period of leave without pay would not count as service for any purpose, thus affecting recreation leave credit, long service leave and sick leave accrual dates.
(5) Does the Minister agree that the scenario outlined in question 4 would actively discourage civilian employees of the department from undertaking reserve service.

(6) Why are civilian employees in the department penalised in the terms outlined in question 4 for reserve service with the ADF when, in effect, they continue to work for the same Government department.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The conditions under which members of the Australian Public Service (APS) can take leave from their normal employment to perform service with the Army, Royal Australian Navy or Royal Australian Air Force reserves are specifically prescribed under Division 3 of Public Service Determination No. 1983/10.

(2) No. Although the Department is extremely sympathetic to requests put to it by civilian staff who wish to engage in reserve activities, Defence is ultimately bound to adhere to the conditions of service which are centrally prescribed for all APS officers. Where flexibility is possible in such matters, the Department will of course extend it to its staff.

(3) In regard to the objectives of paragraph 7.29 of the 1994 Defence White Paper, Navy and Air Force have developed policies which will provide reservists with more opportunity to develop experience through more part-time service. Army's Wellesley Study will enhance the opportunities for reservists to increase their level of experience through improved access to Regular training courses.

In regard to the objectives of paragraph 7.39 of the 1994 Defence White Paper, market research conducted by Frank Small & Associates, concerning the employer and community attitudes to reserves has recently been completed. This information, together with research currently being conducted by Army, will be used to develop employer support policies.

(4) The scenario provided is premised on leave without pay being approved under clause 2.3.18 of Public Service Determination No. 1983/10. In most cases leave without pay for reserve service would be approved under clause 2.3.19, which allows for approved leave to count as service for all purposes except the accrual of recreation leave credits.
(5) No—based on the premise that leave would ordinarily be granted under clause 2.3.19 of Public Service Determination No. 1983/10.
(6) Civilian employees of the department are treated in accordance with APS-wide guidelines and are therefore not subject to any penalty.
