TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 8 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Why was it necessary to change the name of AIDAB to AusAID.
(2) What was the total cost of the change in name.
(3) What amount of stationery became obsolete due to the change in name.
(4) What consultants were employed/hired to oversee the change in name.
(5) What was the cost of changing the signs at AusAID offices.
(6) What was the cost of any direct marketing done to announce the change in name.
(7) Who was notified.
(8) What strategies were used to announce the change in name.
(9) What was the cost of these strategies.
(10) As a percentage of the aid distributed by AusAID, what was the cost of the change in name.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) There was a low level of public recognition of the Agency's previous name and acronym. The old acronym did not signify a clear connection with overseas aid. A community attitudes survey conducted in 1994 confirmed this. The survey found that only one in ten people had heard of the organisation, and less than one third of those knew what the AIDAB acronym stood for. When spelt out AIDAB was a cumbersome and complicated title. The new name, AusAID, is easy to use and readily identifies the nature of the Agency's work; AusAID is Australian aid. It is the Government's hope and expectation that a better knowledge of what AusAID is will lead to more interest in, and support for, the Australian overseas aid program which AusAID administers.
(2) The cost of the name change was $79,500. This includes design work, signage, the launch at Parliament House and postage.

(3) Existing stocks of stationery were run down prior to the launch in order to minimise costs. Stocks of AIDAB stationery remaining at the time of the name change will continue to be used within AusAID until exhausted. There is a reduced need for new printed stationery in AusAID as the Agency has adopted the use of computer generated macros for producing a variety of stationery; for example, ministerial submissions, minute paper and letterhead.

(4) No consultants were employed to oversee the change in name. The only services sourced outside AusAID in relation to the name change were for logo and publication design. Costs for these services are included in the figure provided in response to Question 2.
(5) The cost of changing the signs at AusAID offices amounted to $35,320.

(6) No direct marketing was used to announce the name change. However, as noted in relation to Question 8 below, letters were sent to Members of Parliament, Government officials, non-government organisations and community representatives informing them of the name change.

(7) Individuals and organisations notified of the name change were: selected Heads of Government and other ministers in South Pacific island countries; Ambassadors and High Commissioners accredited to Australia; all members of the Commonwealth Parliament; media; non-government organisations; Commonwealth government departments; businesses involved in the delivery of the aid program; Australian tertiary institutions; and heads of donor agencies.

(8) Letters and information about the name change were sent by mail to a broad range of people, organisations and governments as indicated in response to Question 7. In addition, a photographic exhibition titled AusAID Works for a Better World was opened in Parliament House in conjunction with the announcement of the name change.
(9) The cost of the strategies noted in the preceding answer amounted to approximately $31,000, out of the total cost of $79,500 noted in response to Question 2.
(10) The cost of the name change and launch represented 0.005 per cent of the total 1994-95 aid program and 0.17 per cent of the 1994-95 administration costs of the aid program.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Children with Disabilities: Access to Pre-School Programs

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 10 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that many Australian children with disabilities are unable to gain access to preschool programs because they do not have transport or sufficient resources to assist with transportation.
(2) Which level of Australian government is responsible for ensuring that pre-schoolers with disabilities gain access to pre-school programs.
(3) (a) What is the total allocation of funding the Commonwealth provides to Victoria to assist pre-schoolers with disabilities; and
(b) Who is responsible for decisions at the State level as to how this funding is distributed.
(4) (a) How is this funding distributed in Victoria at the State level;
(b) what accountability mechanisms does the Commonwealth have in place;
(c) can an assurance be given that these funds reach the children they are intended to help; and
(d) can an assurance be given that the desired outcomes for the program are achieved.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2) Responsibility for ensuring that pre-schoolers with disabilities gain access to pre-school programs lies with State Governments.
(3) (a) The Commonwealth provides to Victoria $4.503 million under the Intervention Support sub-component of the National Equity Program for Schools. These funds may be used to assist:
children with disabilities who are below school age;
school students with severe disabilities; and
children in residential care (with or without disabilities).

(b) The bulk of these funds ($3.7 million) is administered by the Victorian Department of Health and Community Services on behalf of the Commonwealth. The remaining funds are distributed through the education authorities (government, Catholic and independent). Under the National Equity Program for Schools agreements each education authority and the Department of Health and Community Services are responsible for the distribution of the funding, based on the advice of advisory committees with representation from parent, teacher and non-school organisations.
(4) (a) The government, Catholic and independent education authorities and the Department of Health and Community Services are responsible for the administration of these funds in Victoria.
(b) Under the National Equity Program for Schools, education authorities are required to provide financial and educational accountability reports by 30 June following the close of the program year.
(c) Education authorities have reported that funds have been applied for the purposes for which they were intended.

(d) An evaluation of the National Equity Program for Schools which includes the Intervention Support sub-component is proposed in 1997 and again in 2000. This evaluation is intended to provide information on achievement of outcomes.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Children with Disabilities: Volunteer Driver Service

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 10 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that the volunteer driver service funded by the Home and Community Care (HACC) and run from the Delatite Shire Council in Victoria is not accessible to children with disabilities.
(2) Why are children with disabilities who try to access this service told it is only for pensioners.
(3) Why are children with disabilities who have received other HACC-funded services told they are ineligible to use this HACC-funded service.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Human Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The organisation has been contacted by the Department of Human Services and Health and has responded that it has no policy to exclude children with disabilities from its service.

I understand that the matter raised in the question related to a one-off incident which occurred a few weeks ago when the carer of a school student requested that the service transport the child directly from school to a "riding for disabled" recreational program on a regular basis. The request for transport was during school hours (9.15am/10am through to 11.15am) and was to include the `Integration Aide' from the student's school.

The service has advised the Department that it has not restricted access by children with disabilities, but that due to the limited funding available and that volunteers, rather than paid professional drivers were used, it was not able to meet all the transport needs of people with disabilities in the Shire. Eligibility for the service is based on assessed relative need and priority is given to clients who are financially disadvantaged and unable to access other forms of transport.
The Department has since been advised that the Community Options/Linkages service has agreed to pay for the transport of the student by the local taxi service.
(2) The organisation denies that such a comment would have been made and has no policy to limit the service to pensioners.

As a recipient of HACC funding, the service is required to consider the needs of the full range of the target group, within available resources, and in accordance with the assessment of relative need.
(3) As outlined above, priority is given to those clients who are both financially disadvantaged and not able to access other transport services more appropriate to their needs.

A number of alternative arrangements were discussed with the carer and the situation has been resolved. The Shire's Community Options/Linkages project will pay for the child's transport by the local taxi service.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 11 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Australian International Education Foundation and regarding the issue of overseas education exhibitions run by IDP Education Australia:
(1) What peak industry education bodies are invited to participate in generic educational exhibitions run overseas by IDP Education Australia.
(2) What are the objectives of the generic exhibitions referred to.
(3) Why was the English Language Intensive Courses for Overseas Students (ELICOS) Association prevented from participating in generic overseas education exhibitions.
(4) Why were no ELICOS general promotional brochures distributed at IDP Education Australia overseas exhibitions.
(5) (a) At what locations overseas have IDP exhibitions been conducted in 1995; and (b) how many times has ELICOS participated.
(6) What are the criteria for being given access to a place on the promotional stands at IDP Australia overseas exhibitions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

PARA.TAB: IDP has been established as an independent not for profit company by the Australian Vice Chancellors' Committee (AVCC) to facilitate, among other things, the enrolment of overseas students in Australian universities and other educational institutions. Its activities include the conduct of education exhibitions and promotions on a commercial basis.

IDP sets both its pricing and participation policies for the education exhibitions which it promotes on a commercial basis without reference to either the Department of Employment, Education and Training or the Australian International Education Foundation (AIEF). IDP's past use of the Australian Education Centre (AEC) banner for many of these exhibitions has been interpreted by providers as government endorsement for IDP's participation policies. Under new arrangements from the beginning of 1995, IDP can no longer use the AEC banner for exhibitions without the approval of the AIEF.

IDP is an independent commercial operation of the AVCC. As it is a company in which the Australian Government, the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the Australian International Education Foundation have no financial interest, the Senator should direct his questions regarding IDP's exhibition participation policies to the AVCC and the IDP.

The AIEF has not itself conducted any education exhibitions during 1995. At the request of education agents in Taiwan (including IDP) an education exhibition was conducted under AIEF auspices in Taipei during August 1995. IDP was the managing agent for this exhibition. The conditions for the exhibition were negotiated between education agents, a member of the AIEF Council and IDP. All institutions registered on the Commonwealth Register of Institutions and Courses for Overseas Students (CRICOS) were invited to participate in the exhibition. Peak education bodies were also invited to participate. Peak education bodies were permitted to have their own booths to promote their sectoral issues. The ELICOS Association was invited to participate in the Taipei exhibition on that basis but chose not to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 11 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the countries and higher education institutions that have entered into agreements with OLAA.
(2) What charges will be levied by the OLAA for the courses offered.
(3) How many of the OLAA consortium partners will be involved in overseas course delivery.
(4) What problems were encountered by the OLAA during the reported international trial of their courses in Russia using the Internet.
(5) What modes of delivery does the OLAA intend to utilise to fulfil the delivery of courses.
(6) What subject areas will be offered to international clients.

(7) What level of scrutiny and quality control of the teaching materials, methods and student services will be undertaken to ensure that Australia's reputation as a provider of quality higher education courses will not be damaged in any way.

(8) Can a guarantee be given that, before the OLAA enters into the world market offering higher education products, the problems with domestic course content, quality and student services already identified by the Senate Employment, Education and Training References Committee will be addressed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The OLAA has advised that it has entered into the following agreements:

with the Association for International Education, in Moscow, to conduct a pilot scheme for selected students to study towards an Australian business studies degree using OLAA study units, taught from the relevant Australian provider universities;

a statement of intent with the Hong Kong Open Learning Institute for the provision of selected OLAA study units for teaching by Australian provider institutions and the provision of off shore tutorial support services for Hong Kong based OLAA students;
a statement of intent with the University of Humberside in the United Kingdom for the purchase of study materials used with selected OLAA units, for use in University of Humberside courses;

a statement of intent with Harbridge Management Consultants Pty Ltd in Singapore for the provision of selected OLAA study units for teaching by Australian provider institutions and the provision of off shore tutorial support services for Singapore based OLAA students;
a statement of intent with a consulting group in Malaysia for the offering of study units, including existing OLAA units, for professional training at the undergraduate level in Malaysia; and

a statement of intent with the Pedagogical University in Warsaw, Poland to examine the feasibility of establishing a Polish-Australian Open University in Poland. The OLAA is providing consultancy services to develop a business plan for discussion later this year.
(2) The OLAA has advised the following charges are levied for courses offered:
for Singapore and Hong Kong students, the OLAA fee for overseas students will apply. This is currently $410 per study unit;
for other proposals currently under discussion, fee levels have not yet been determined.

(3) The OLAA has advised that Charles Sturt University, Curtin University of Technology, Monash University, the University of Adelaide, the University of South Australia and the University of Southern Queensland currently offer units through the OLAA for credit towards business/commerce degrees. These universities will be invited to offer these units in Singapore and Hong Kong. The same universities will also be invited to offer these units in the Russian Pilot Scheme.
Details of the proposals for Poland and Malaysia have yet to be determined. Provider institutions to be invited to be involved are those currently offering the units required through the OLAA.

(4) The OLAA has advised that activities trialled involved simulated student-lecturer interaction by e-mail and the electronic transmission, annotation and return of assignments between Moscow and the OLAA offices in Melbourne. The Agency has advised that it is not aware of any difficulties encountered during these trials.

(5) The OLAA has advised that it intends to use airmail dispatch of print study materials from provider universities to students in Singapore and Hong Kong. For those units with TV components, video cassettes will be purchased by the offshore education providers for use by students in tutorial sessions.

(6) The OLAA has advised that off shore demand for its courses has been primarily in the business and related disciplines. It also advises that it will seek to meet off shore demand for other courses delivered through the OLAA.

(7) The OLAA has advised that for the proposed operations in Singapore and Hong Kong, units will be taught and assessed from Australia by the relevant provider universities with off shore tutorial support. The OLAA advises that existing quality control standards on the delivery of units under its individual agreements with each Australian provider university will be used to control the quality of teaching materials, methods and student services for units provided off shore. The OLAA advises that it will monitor overseas operations through visits by academic consultants of the OLAA who will ensure that resources and standards meet those that apply in Australia.

(8) The OLAA has advised that it has a number of quality assurance processes currently in place. Unit providers are selected through a public tender with appraisal by independent academic reference panels which make recommendations to the OLAA Academic Programs Board. All units selected for offer through OLAA are accredited within the provider institutions and have been subjected to those institutions' internal quality assurance processes.

With regard to its international operations, the OLAA advises that it will ensure that the quality of offshore tutorial support provided is of high standard. As stated above, a number of units are being taught from Australia. For those units taught overseas, academic consultants will visit overseas countries to ensure that resources and services meet the standards of quality assurance set.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 22 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: What is the best current estimate of the total amount of capital invested by retired Australians?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The best current estimate of the total amount of capital invested by retired Australians is between $330 billion and $360 billion as at March 1995, compared with around $1200 billion for all Australians.
This estimate includes financial assets of around $110 billion and housing assets of around $240 billion.
The estimate is compiled by applying asset holdings from the 1989/90 ABS Income Distribution Survey to the March 1995 Financial Accounts of the Australian National Accounts.

The estimate of financial assets of around $110 billion held by retirees is consistent with estimates based on data from the Department of Social Security of financial assets of around $40 billion for age pensioners in 1994.
Assumptions underlying the analysis are:
Retired persons are:
—single persons over 55 years of age and not in the labour force, or
—married couples where one person is over 55 years of age and both are not in the labour force.
Asset holding ratios for retired persons have not significantly changed since 1989/90.
Retired persons hold between 5%-15% of reserves of life offices and pension funds.
Housing equity has been inflated by the growth in the Dwelling Implicit Price Deflator of 7.9% between 1989/90 and March 1995.
